name: Stella Kyriakides
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, we are nearing the end of one of the most challenging and most consequential years in recent memory. First of all, as I look back on 2020, the feeling I have is of being heartbroken for so many lives that have been lost. But I also feel pride and I feel gratitude when I think of all the frontline workers and all the doctors and nurses who have sacrificed, how neighbours have rallied around each other, and how the European Union came together to support citizens of Member States.  I’m also reminded of an old saying that those who do not learn from history are condemned to repeat it, and COVID-19 has taught us some harsh lessons, lessons that we are still learning. It has reminded us of the foundational role that health plays in our societies and our economies. It has highlighted the vital importance of solidarity, and this has amplified structural vulnerabilities in our health system. The Commission is determined to heed these lessons and take decisive action in partnership with the European Parliament and Member States.  Yesterday, we adopted an ambitious pharmaceutical strategy for Europe. It is an important building block in a genuine European health union and I am truly delighted to have the opportunity to discuss it with you. This strategy addresses both the short-term challenges linked to COVID-19 and the long-term challenges connected with unmet medical needs, Europe’s strategic autonomy and sustainable health systems.  I will share with you that this was a strategy that was in my mandate letter from President von der Leyen one year ago. When I saw it there, I knew that we were faced with challenges with the pharmaceutical situation in Europe, but I never imagined that we would be presenting it in the COVID—19 crisis. It has changed a lot and we have adjusted many things in this strategy from what we have learned in this pandemic.  It focuses on four key areas. First and foremost, improving patients’ access to affordable medicines. Secondly, ensuring innovation to boost the potential of our pharmaceutical industry and increasing support for unmet medical needs of patients. This includes harnessing the benefits of emerging science and technology and reducing the environmental footprint. It is no good having innovation if you cannot have this reach patients. Third, building strategic autonomy, developing resilient and diverse types of supply chains, and addressing the root causes of shortages of medicines. This includes the European Health Emergency Response Authority (HERA), which will enable the EU and its Member States to rapidly deploy the most advanced medical and other measures in the event of a health emergency. And finally, fourth, to promote EU influence and competitiveness at global level and ensure a level playing field for EU operators. So the pharmaceutical strategy aims to cover the whole life cycle of medicine, from research to clinical trials and authorisation, from consumption to safe disposal.  Honourable Members, the current pharmaceutical legislation has served us well. However, we are now living in a vastly different reality. We have to take a holistic view of the pharmaceutical legislation and make the necessary improvements to ensure it is better adapted for today’s world. Over the next two years, we will work hard on the reform of the pharmaceutical legislation. This reform will address all the angles I mentioned, but always putting the patient at the centre and always ensuring that our pharmaceutical industry maintains its global leadership. This applies to the framework for medicines, for children and rare diseases.  However, this strategy is not just about changes to legislation. We will also simplify the regulatory procedure allowing quicker access to innovative and affordable medicines for patients, such as gene-editing technologies and personalised treatments; to facilitate the development of novel antibiotics and to combat antimicrobial resistance; to increase the uptake of generics and biosimilars. We will also create a health data space where regulators and the industry can exchange data for the benefit of patients and provide for simple solutions such as electronic product information. At the same time, we will revise our system of initiatives for research and development to ensure those incentives are fair and balanced while allowing the EU industry to remain innovative and competitive worldwide. We will also take action to make medicines more environmentally friendly.  Last, but definitely not least, we aim to address shortages of medicines by reinforcing the current obligations for supply, and require an early notification of interruption. In parallel, we will strengthen coordination with key stakeholders and industry and patient associations by establishing a structural dialogue to better understand vulnerabilities in the supply chain.  I just want to end by saying a few words. There are thousands of European Union citizens who are today suffering from rare diseases, and there are thousands of families who have children with cancer, and they do not have access to the medicines that we would want them to have that would give them a better quality of life and hope. The way forward with this is to encourage innovation and to make sure that no matter where you live, no matter which Member State you belong to, you have equal access to safe and affordable and innovative medicines.  The road is not going to be easy, and this is a strategy that is a vision, and it is a vision with actions that will be developing over the next four years. We already have a very buoyant, and I would say a front-runner, in the pharmaceutical industry in Europe, but we can do better and we now have the opportunity, so it’s up to all of us – the European Parliament, the Council and definitely the Commission. If we work together, we can bring together new legislation, but also other actions that are really going to change the realities for access to medicines for citizens across the Member States, and this is a responsibility that we will definitely do our best to stand up to.

name: Dolors Montserrat
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, one of the lessons of the COVID-19 pandemic is that we have accelerated the construction of a European Health Union, and this new Pharmaceutical Strategy is an opportunity to cement one of the pillars of this new Europe for health. With this Strategy we must be able to deal with any pandemic or health threat, put the patient at the centre of all decisions, address unsuced medical needs, ensure access to medicines for all, strengthen the competitiveness of European industry and make Europe a world leader in research and health care. We must invest more in the fight against antimicrobial resistance and its rapid spread, which threatens Europe with more than 33,000 people who die each year. Today there are more than 7,000 rare diseases, 95% of them unin treatment. We must respond to patients and their families in the face of this great despair. We have a big gap in pediatric drug research and development, and our children come first. And we cannot allow a European cancer patient to have a difference of between 7% and 90% chance of access to approved medicines. Or that you have to wait between 90 and 1,000 days for a drug to be marketed after it has been approved. The Strategy should also strengthen the competitiveness of the pharmaceutical industry, fostering a stable and robust regulatory system, improving government procurement, streamlining approval procedures without sacrificing safety and facilitating the making available of quality medicines. Technological and digital transformation must also be a reality, using artificial intelligence to improve early detection and advance innovative and personalized treatments. And we must boost production in Europe and our industrial autonomy so as not to depend on third countries. There are many challenges ahead of us and we must respond to each of them. And to achieve this we must work together in the public and private sectors. Only in this way will we strike a balance between innovation, accessibility to innovation and the sustainability of national health systems. Only in this way will we protect one of the great fundamental rights, the health of all, and with great hope for all.

name: Heléne Fritzon
text: On the other: And on the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I would like to thank Commissioner Kyriakides for her excellent introduction. Within the S&D Group, we welcome the fact that the Commission has now presented the pharmaceutical strategy to the EU. It is an important step on the road to a European Health Union in which we lay the foundations for europe to better manage the risks that we face at the moment in the pandemic, but also in the future. Medicines provide great opportunities to both cure and alleviate diseases, but we also have a lot of challenges. We must ensure that we have equal access to medicines for the whole population. We must also have environmentally sustainable drug use. The use must be effective and safe, and the cost-treatment ratio must be reasonable. In the S&D Group, we have long called for increased measures to ensure access to safe, effective and affordable medicines. We knew and we see that even before the Covid-19 crisis there were shortcomings, and we now see that it is very gratifying that the Commission is proposing concrete measures. It is an excellent opportunity to strengthen patient safety. The patient perspective must be in focus, while it is important that we look at industrial and competition issues. The Covid-19 pandemic has shown the shortcomings. We must ensure that Europe will never again experience a shortage of medicines and medical equipment. We will also have new pandemic threats in the future. So I expect this to lead to concrete action and this, ladies and gentlemen of europe, is the citizens of Europe. They have the right to expect this from the EUROPEAN Union.

name: Véronique Trillet-Lenoir
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, Commissioner, through this pharmaceutical strategy we have a duty to ensure that European citizens have timely and fair access to innovative, rigorously evaluated, affordable and constantly available medicines. Innovative, because they are the result of cutting-edge European research for all diseases, including the rarest. And we welcome the revision of European legislation on medicines dedicated to children's diseases, in particular cancers and rare diseases. It is very important, it is a question of justice and fairness. Rigorously evaluated. And it will be important to convince heads of government to unblock the Health Technology Assessment (HTA) regulation. This will give us the means to determine the added value of medicines together. Affordable, because this added value will determine value and improve price convergence. You are starting this by proposing enhanced cooperation between The Member States, but it will soon be necessary to bring about a revision of the directive on the transparency of price-fixing measures. Finally, constantly available, combating shortages by strengthening the control missions of the Medicines Agency and by restoring European pharmaceutical independence. You are asking for a study, it will have to lead to concrete measures. Let us thus return together to the virtuous circle: research, evaluation, pricing, procurement, which is the foundation of Europe's drug, of which you have laid the foundation today.

name: Joëlle Mélin
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, you want to build a pharmaceutical strategy for Europe, which aims to ensure the quality and safety of the drug. But it is exactly the same reason that led to the creation, 16 years ago, of the European Medicines Agency, which already establishes the Community procedures for authorising surveillance and pharmacovigilance of medicines for human and veterinary use. You add that you want to improve and speed up patients' access to medicines at affordable and safe prices. But how are you going to get the support of MPs, almost all of whose groups rejected a report on access to medicines that I brought in 2016 and which was written in exactly the same terms? You are still saying that we will have to support the innovation of the pharmaceutical industry, of course, but first we will have to restore fair competition rules that no longer encourage our larger groups to relocate 80% of the generic active ingredients to China or India. The COVID crisis was only a sign of an untenable and old situation that had the effect of increasing drug shortages in France by 20 times in less than 10 years. And this is a direct consequence of your globalist policy. To have stock control, you are calling for even more Europe, through Europe's health, by expanding the competences of the European Medicines Agency, in particular through new technologies, and by creating an interconnected health system. But who guarantees that this data will not be immediately recovered by insurers or by foreign digital providers? You also talk about the fight against cancer. Of course, a special commission has just been set up, but we have been waiting since a resolution in 2016 for the paediatric regulation to be revised with regard to the fight against childhood cancer. You want, wisely, thanks to the Horizon Europe device, artificial intelligence and digitization, to accelerate research and innovation. But how can you assure us that the results and publications will be there, when one year after the launch of aid for research on COVID, we still have no actionable feedback to redirect states in their health strategy? So once again, at the turn of a seemingly acceptable project and on the grounds of future challenges, you are far beyond your prerogatives and, with regard to what is only one therapeutic possibility among others, you are cementing a real formatting tool of the European health care sector that will deprive Member States of all autonomy in their management. That is why, instead of building this fragile system, we propose cooperation between states that allows us to use existing tools. This is to enable the relocation of generic production in Europe and France, to ensure locally all stages of production, in sufficient quantity and production, to ensure good manufacturing practices, to ensure the transparency of stocks, to ensure the tracing and labelling of boxes at all stages, to finally put an end to the quota policy and to limit , as far as possible, parallel trade, make regulations more flexible, allow a price and cost policy that stabilizes margins, and thus markets and, ultimately, save our national systems.

name: Kim Van Sparrentak
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, we all agree that our health is one of the greatest goods we have. This year, we stayed at home collectively to ensure no one’s health would be jeopardised. As a society, we have evolved to foster our public health by producing treatments such as vaccines, and we have managed to eradicate many diseases from the face of the earth. But it seems as if the progress made is now being stalled by the greed of the shareholders of the big pharmaceutical companies because, in a profit—driven pharmaceutical industry, treatments for rare diseases won’t bring enough profit and, if medicines can be sold for a higher price in one Member State, we apparently accept that medicines are not available for the people who need them elsewhere. And, when there is a pandemic, we don’t get a patent pool because that goes against the interest of big corporations.  This is not what the European health union should look like, and I’m glad that in the Pharmaceutical Strategy the Commission acknowledges this. But how, then, does the Commission delay real action for change? Hasn’t the Commission faced the problem of a too powerful and profit—driven pharmaceutical industry first hand when negotiating for the COVID vaccine in the past year? We need to start to change now.  We call upon the Commission to step up against the abuses of dominant positions in the pharmaceutical sector, to demand transparency on development costs as part of the requirements for public subsidies, and to update intellectual property rules to better reflect innovation. Only then can we truly say that we put patients over profits and ensure accessible medicines for all European citizens.

name: Joanna Kopcińska
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Honourable Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. The Pharmaceutical Strategy for Europe aims to address public health problems by creating forward-looking regulatory solutions and ensuring equal access to medicines for patients. On the one hand, technological and scientific development contributes to innovative treatment and, on the other hand, technology itself poses a challenge to the regulatory framework and leads to the creation of unintended barriers. On this point, we need to make qualitative changes. We should strengthen affordability in the area of medicines and ensure equal access without excluding anyone. Moreover, the current coronavirus pandemic has further exacerbated the problem of our continent's lack of drug independence and the high sensitivity of the supply chain. As shadow rapporteur for the current EU4Health programme, but also shadow rapporteur in the already adopted report on the lack of medicines, I am responsible for partially transferring the production of key substances back to our continent. Financial incentives at European Union level that favour the production of active substances and other semi-manufacturing measures here in Europe should be considered. Only diversification of suppliers will increase the drug safety of our continent. We must also rethink the appropriate policy for the creation of stocks of medicines in the Member States.  Complementarity and synergies between the pharmaceutical strategy and the EU4Health programme, the cancer eradication plan, the lack of medicines report and the health package currently being presented by the Commission will only be effective if it is based on respect for the division of competences in the field of health policy. For this reason, we must act horizontally at EU level, taking into account closely the proposals of Member States that already have knowledge of the availability of critical medicines on their territory.

name: Kateřina Konečná
text: for the GUE/NGL group. – Mr President, while I do not do this very often, first of all, let me commend the Commission. I personally welcome the fact that one of the four main objectives is to ensure that patients have access to affordable medicines and to address shortcomings in the treatment needs for children and patients with rare diseases. We need this revision like salt, and after all, I myself have been calling for it in the European Parliament for six years. I therefore very much hope that joint purchases of orphan drugs at European Union level will be part of the revision, because in recent months it has become clear that, if the Commission wants to, joint purchases are going, and I see no reason not to do so with orphan drugs. However, I would expect the new strategy to mention patent law at World Health Organisation level, because, as we have found out, a number of the current rules on global trade simply do not help us to deal with any major health crisis. At this point, I would therefore like once again to call on both the Commission and the World Health Organisation to participate as actively as possible in tackling this problem in the Fair Prices Forum. If we do not make a major impact on this regulation, access to medicines and their price will improve very little, and pharmaceutical companies will continue to make money and citizens will be forced to pay. Colleagues, I see the proposal so far positively, but I see a lot of white spots in it. However, we have a lot of work to do and I am looking forward to it.

name: Λευτέρης Νικολάου-Αλαβάνος (NI).
text: Mr President, intensive care units are filling in suffocation, criminal gaps in beds and staff are being shelved, and the Greek Government, on the one, is making infuriating comparisons of the dead by country, provocatively claiming that increasing intensive care units will increase the number of deaths, while reducing health funding by 600 million. For protection measures on public transport and in workplaces not a word, since they do not serve the profitability of entrepreneurs.  Vaccines, provided they are safe and effective, will help tackle the pandemic. However, this does not erase the huge shortcomings in public health systems, from the EU strategy of privatising hospitals and commercialising health that has led to millions of deaths. At the same time, pharmaceutical companies and capitalist states are engaged in a competition race for vaccine-merchandise. Agreements hide unknown and dangerous conditions for the people. Valuable information is hidden behind patents, depriving the timely exchange of scientific data, the necessary interdisciplinary cooperation that could improve efficacy and safety and speed up the disposal of vaccines.  Folks need to know. That is why we have asked the Commission to reveal the terms of the contracts. Contracts paid for with money from the heavy taxation of the peoples of the European Union, as well as the clauses signed by the European Union with pharmaceutical bees. The peoples of Europe should demand that the vaccine be made available free of charge to all without discrimination or categorization on the basis of its price. Prioritise the requisition of private clinics at no price and the shielding of public health systems. Equipment and staffing with permanent staff with decent salaries so that they can cope with fixed and emergency needs.

name: Cindy Franssen (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, if the corona crisis has taught us anything, it is that the EU must be given a stronger role in such a health crisis, it is that we must make our system resilient and crisis-proof. The new pharmaceutical strategy is inherently linked to this.  Equal access for each patient to innovative medicines and treatments is often a utopia. That is why this stronger cooperation between Member States is so important for more correct pricing and reimbursement. Boosting innovation in the sector: with the right incentives, this can be done, so that investing can once again become attractive, also for the development of orphan medicines. But also, Commissioner, with the necessary transparency, because artificially keeping prices high is unacceptable. We strengthen the supply chain by creating strategic reserves, by reducing our dependence on third countries to a minimum and by investing in European production. Let's be back in that cockpit as a world leader.  The vaccination strategy shows that strong European cooperation pays off. So yes, the EU needs to be given a stronger role in the global health context. It is time to make the best use of the Union's scale in the interests of equal access for all patients. We need to give patients perspective, a hopeful horizon.  I would like to congratulate you, Commissioner, on your ambitious plan, and we look forward to the further roll-out of the concrete initiatives. As an EPP, we will work constructively on this.

name: Jytte Guteland (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr All people have the right to good health, quality care, safe and effective medicines that everyone can afford. It is fundamental to the fair welfare society and it must be fundamental for the whole of Europe. The Corona crisis has unequivocally shown that this is not the case. Under a huge challenge, as this pandemic has brought to our Member States and our peoples, europe has not always worked as well as it should have and as one might expect. In several Member States, people have suffered from a shortage of basic medicines, vital medical devices, such as ventilators, hand sanitizers, face masks. It is not worthy of europe. Europe and the Member States must learn from these experiences. We must take a new approach in order to strengthen cooperation in the field of health. Not least in the case of medicines, and in the case of pricing, payment and procurement of medicinal products. It is therefore good that the Commission is now taking this approach through this pharmaceutical strategy, and we in the Socialist Group welcome the Commission's proposal. We particularly welcome the fact that eu legislation on medicines in particular is being reviewed and measures to increase transparency in pricing are being reviewed. This is important. All people in Europe should have equal access to high-quality, affordable medicines, and we expect concrete tools from the Commission here.

name: Jan Huitema (Renew).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Ladies commissioner, thank you for bringing this comprehensive pharmaceutical strategy to the fore. Nevertheless, I am missing a concrete plan to tackle the shortages of medicines in Europe. Your strategy only mentions that the problem of drug shortages needs to be identified. Unfortunately, it doesn't get any more concrete than that. We must wait until 2022 for new legislation. That's taking me way too long!  In the Netherlands alone, we have seen that in 2019 1 500 resources were not available for a long time. Year after year, the number of drug shortages is growing. A year ago, you announced that you would be coming up with such a pharmaceutical strategy. We in the European Parliament have indicated several times that we want to see a solution to the shortages of medicines. Why is this strategy not offering that solution now? Why do we not demand security of supply when purchasing medicines, or do we require that some medicines should be produced in the European Union, instead of just looking at the price of the medicines? As many as 80% of the pills we take in Europe come from Asia.  Can you make sure that we have this discussion as soon as possible? Because a lot of people need medicine now and can't wait another two years.

name: Marco Dreosto (ID).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I welcome Commissioner Kyriakides, who is here with us today. We still have in our eyes and in our memory the tragic moments when, at the outbreak of the first wave of covid-19 pandemic, the European Union was in fact completely unprepared for the management of the health crisis. So, Commissioner, initiatives by the European Commission are welcome to prevent this situation from happening again in any way. Never forgetting the fundamental principle of subsidiarity and the competences of the Member States, greater coordination and a push to do more at European level are certainly welcome. There is no joke about the health and health of our citizens. It is necessary to guarantee safe, quality and above all accessible pharmaceutical products for all. It is also necessary to promote competitiveness and innovation in the pharmaceutical sector, while also guaranteeing the highest criteria – I repeat, the highest criteria – for transparency. The principle of European autonomy in the pharmaceutical field must be strongly reaffirmed, so that we are not dependent on states that have shown, even in the very recent past, that they are totally unreliable. Any reference to China is no accident. The question of access for medicines to all, regardless of social and economic status, is of absolute importance. Health must not be a question of rank, health is a fundamental right, a right for all. That is precisely why we must also seek synergistic cooperation with pharmaceutical companies in order to develop medicines, even if they are not commercially attractive, precisely in order to guarantee this universally recognised right. I am thinking, for example, of rare diseases and their treatments, in particular paediatric oncology, children who fall ill with cancer or leukaemia. In Europe, I would remind you, around 35 000 cases are diagnosed each year between children and adolescents. Of these, tragic, at least 6 000 are destined to die, without treatment. Too much. For this reason, new drugs are needed, more effective, safer, with fewer side effects in the short and long term. The parents of these children and these children are asking us, and they are asking us all, regardless of their political colour. It is not a political battle of the League, the People's Party or the Socialists. It is a battle for all of us, and that is why, Commissioner, I would like to see the greatest possible cooperation in parliament between all the political forces on such an important and sensitive issue as health.

name: Tilly Metz (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, the strategy is welcome. The COVID crisis has clearly highlighted the problems that patients and health professionals have long denounced: lack of access to medicines, high prices and lack of treatment. The Commission is therefore making the right findings, but I regret that it does not get to the bottom of the problem: our dependence on the pharmaceutical industry. And to rebalance this balance of power, several actions are needed. First, the realization of group purchases so that no country is disadvantaged. Second, transparency about the costs of research and development of a drug. The same should be true for obtaining conditions of exclusivity. Thirdly, public research should be one of the pillars of the European Union's action. Why not fund university centres to develop skills centres instead of industry? Why not create a European public centre for the production of active substances to avoid the shortage of medicines? This strategy is an opportunity to rethink our relationship with medicines and to strengthen the European Union, considering medicines, not as commercial goods, but as basic necessities.

name: Beata Kempa (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by This strategy is very necessary because the coronavirus epidemic has once again demonstrated the disastrous effects of european industrial policy to this day. The restrictions, strict environmental and climate standards introduced for years have led to industry escaping beyond the borders of the European Union. Pharmaceuticals are also subject to market law, which is why today 80% of active pharmaceutical ingredients and 40% of finished medicines sold in Europe come from China and India. Without the precursors sent to Europe, we are unable to meet the shortcomings. Between 2000 and 2018, drug shortages in the European Union increased 20fold. For years, the Union has not made any breakthrough in the treatment of cancer patients, and moreover, 95% of rare disease patients seek help outside the European Union. We cannot find an answer to drug-resistant strains of bacteria or the silent outbreak of Lyme disease. That is why today we need to quickly remove years of neglect and, above all, to restore the production of medicines to Europe and shorten supply chains.

name: Manuel Bompard (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, your pharmaceutical strategy will not respond to the urgency of the moment. We do not need a strategy that seeks to support the competitiveness of the pharmaceutical industry, we need a public health policy that focuses on the interests of patients and not on the interests of pharmaceutical companies. Drug shortages have been around for years. The COVID-19 crisis has only revealed its magnitude and disastrous consequences. It is the ongoing search for lower costs by pharmaceutical companies that has led to outsourcing production to fashion makers and a growing search for low-cost labour-using countries for the provision of active ingredients. Today, 80% of the active ingredients of medicines are produced outside the European Union. It is not tenable. We need a European industrial strategy organising the conditions for local public pharmaceutical production. Already, we see laboratories, such as Sanofi, reclaim the watchword of relocation. Under the pretext of creating a European champion, the Pluto project will outsource six European Sanofi plants to a self-contained entity placed on the stock exchange, allowing to pass a savings plan of 2 billion euros, notably through job cuts and outsourcing of activities. This is an outrage. In each Member State, public poles of the drug must be set up. It is not normal for medicines paid twice by citizens, through public research subsidies and reimbursements from social security systems, to abound in shareholder dividends. These drugs must be produced publicly, the only way to ensure price accessibility and transparency. And we must start now with drugs of major therapeutic interest... (the President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Antoni Comín i Oliveres (NI).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, there are too many medicines, vaccines and treatments that have an indisputable medical and social interest, but which do not exist because of the lack of commercial interest of the industry. Orphan drugs for rare diseases are the most obvious case, but not the only one. Vaccines for viruses such as SARS and MERS are another example of this. The Eu ropean Union's pharmaceutical strategy, which is closely linked to its research strategy in the field of health, must ensure that the financial resources necessary to develop those medicines that market logic is unable to provide are mobilised. The new European brand will be an important step in this direction. However, the participation of the public administration in the development of new medicines opens up another debate: what should be their price? For example, the covid-19 vaccine case and the early purchase contract signed by the Commission with five, soon seven pharmaceutical companies. We are paying the costs of developing the vaccine with public funds, in return for speeding up the process. We're just investing to buy time. Should we not also have asked for the sharing of intellectual property? This would have allowed us to pay for the vaccine, when it arrives, at a much lower price than we will probably end up paying. A European pharmaceutical strategy requires fair prices that allow public health systems to reduce their current pharmaceutical spending.

name: Jessica Polfjärd (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr The EU is at its best when we work together on problems that are cross-border, where the EU Member States themselves are unable to deal with or solve the problems. This has been demonstrated by the current pandemic. The new EU pharmaceutical strategy is therefore an important initiative to strengthen European cooperation in the field of public health.  We have to deal with the main problems here and now, but we also have to look to the future and see what threats lie ahead. It is therefore particularly welcome that the initiative clearly prioritises another of the greatest threats of our time: antibiotic resistance. Already today, it reaps over 30 000 European lives every year. If we do not act now, the consequences will be even worse in the future. It is clear that antibiotic resistance cannot be tackled by individual or sporadic measures; There are many good examples across Europe how we can solve this. That is why we must see the development of new antibiotics. We need to review the incentives for research and the public should also take more responsibility. In the process of stopping antibiotic resistance, the EU should and can take greater responsibility.

name: Sara Cerdas (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, colleagues, 2020 marks the most serious year of this pandamic crisis in the last 100 years, but it will also mark the year in which this Union responds in health matters and moves forward, in great steps, towards the creation of a genuine European Union for health.  Despite a good starting point of this strategy, I share some important considerations on two priorities. The first: antimicrobial resistance.  It is time to assume the urgency of this crisis and act as such. The European Union must be a global leader in this battle and the answer lies in the one-health approach. I welcome the Commission at the outset for the proposals put forward, but I would like to see the creation of a special status for antimicrobial substances, which will prove essential to protect these important but scarce therapeutic weapons.  Speaking of scarcity, the second point I would like to address: the shortage of medicines. A scourge that plagues the entire European Union and, in order to achieve accessibility to efficient and innovative medicines, particular attention should be paid to the whole chain and ensure and strengthen fair access to the most remote regions of the European Union, which are the case in the outermost regions.

name: Frédérique Ries (Renew).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, the COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the urgent need to strengthen our health systems and also our over-reliance, immense dependence, on Chinese and Indian drug manufacturers. This applies to widely used antibiotics such as amoxicillin, painkillers, such as aspirin or paracetamol, specialties for thyroid disorders. Desperate patients call on us every day. And you mentioned, Commissioner, medicines for paediatric cancers or rare diseases. In my country, one in five Belgians no longer gets the drug they are looking for. It is not something that can be bearable. The pharmaceutical strategy presented yesterday partially addresses the problems. You are announcing, for 2022, the reform of the Pharma legislation. It must be based on the transparency of the supply chain and the obligation on manufacturers to notify as soon as possible the shortage or even withdrawal of a drug. Shortage, the word is said. You use it 16 times in the text and 13 times the word production, this underlines the urgency. However, we are looking a little at the concrete proposals on the build-up of stockpiles of essential medicines at European level. Why wait and discuss the production of active substances for two years? What incentives do you intend to use - tax, financial or otherwise - to convince industrialists to relocate? Because the bottom line is the problem: relocating to guarantee access while controlling prices. A certainty, and I conclude, Mr President, the Europe of health has, as you said, Commissioner, taken a huge step forward this year. The European Parliament will be at your side in the coming months for a stronger Europe in the primary interests of patients.

name: Jutta Paulus (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Thank you, Mrs Kyriakides, for this strategy and also thank you for including our green demands for environmental aspects in the production and application of pharmaceuticals in your strategy. I would like to focus on one point, which Mrs Polfjärd has already raised, and that is antibiotic resistance. Experts warn that the next pandemic could be triggered by a multi-resistant germ and may be much more drastic than the current COVID-19 pandemic. That is why: yes, it is right to research new antibiotics and to support this research by the state. But it is even more important to prevent these resistances. For example, if waste water is discharged into rivers untreated during production, or if mass animal husbandry is spread in our fields, we should not be surprised that resistance is increasing. Therefore: adopt strict guidelines to limit the use of animal fattening and modernize the rules of good manufacturing practice, so that these aspects are included and production sites worldwide have to comply with these requirements!

name: Marc Botenga (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, we have seen all the power of the major pharmaceutical industries and Big Pharma, which are now deciding what to produce and at what price to sell. People don't trust. You yourself have been ripped off: you made this contract with Gilead for one billion euros, supposedly for a drug against COVID. But by the time you announced this in October, Gilead had already known for two weeks that it actually didn't work very well. What a scam frankly! So the real question we should be asking ourselves is how to free ourselves today from the control, the grip of the big multinational pharmaceutical companies on our lives and our health. And this question, no luck, you have forgotten a little in your pharmaceutical strategy. So if you have a pencil, I'll suggest two measures. Firstly, let us not leave control over the vaccine in the hands of multinational pharmaceutical companies, but let us bring the vaccine under public control and, secondly, we need a public pharmaceutical hub in Europe so that we are no longer dependent on large multinationals for the production of essential medicines.

name: Mislav Kolakušić (NI).
text: – Dear Chairman, the pharmaceutical industry has in the past decades organized several hundred conferences, symposiums, meetings - everything. In the last year, no conference has been organized, not a single symposium on COVID-19, on vaccines.  What's all this about, how is that possible? The main talking man, the chief authority talking about COVID-19, both vaccines and the number of inhabitants on the globe has become the person who assembled computers in his own garage.  People are talking - are there any conspiracy theories? What's all this about? No, this is a precisely elaborated business plan worth several thousand billion euros. Who contributed to that? It was contributed by media that turned into fake news factories, quasi-scientists - their profession has nothing to do with immunology - and so on; made possible by cheap politicians. What does it take to do? It is necessary to put an end to this, it is necessary to talk. We need to talk in this home about vaccines, about ways to treat them. Likewise, professional symposia must be organized, doctors must say. We don't know what the doctors are saying today because they're silent.

name: Sunčana Glavak (PPE).
text: – Dear Chairman, I thank you for this important document, which we strongly supported in Parliament and that, in Parliament, we discuss vaccines and important things. I believe that today we can say that we are one step closer to better managing the system for responding to health crises in the future and I welcome the adoption of the Strategy in the European Commission.  And we MPs pointed to the challenges facing our citizens and the pharmaceutical industry in this pandemic. From shortages and drug prices to the European Union's dependence on third countries and uncertain supply chains. The coronavirus pandemic reminded us that people's health and life are invaluable. That is why we must ensure that our citizens have access to an effective, verified, safe and, of course, most importantly, affordable medicine.  The pharmaceutical industry needs to be our partner in the dialogue, as it is an indispensable player in meeting the goals we set in protecting people's health against cancer, promoting healthy ageing and investing in R&D. The European Parliament called for the creation of a common European pharmacy in a resolution on medicine shortages in September. I suggest we rethink the guidelines and timeline for the realisation of this important proposal. We have successfully organized strategic reserves of protective equipment through rescEU and civil protection mechanism. I believe that model can also be thought of as a way to create drug reserves.  In addition, I invite you to make further efforts to ensure uniform availability of the price of medicines in all Member States.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D).
text: Mr President! I would also like to thank the European Commissioner for presenting this very good and necessary strategy for medicines. The corona crisis has shown us and revealed some of the problems that we already knew. However, supply chains, especially those outside Europe, are difficult, and that is why we need to do something at European level that ensures that we can access and produce important and necessary medicines, either closer to Europe or in Europe. I am also pleased that the patient is being put into focus. It is absolutely essential that we do this in our pharmaceutical strategy. This means that we must make sure that cheap – or at least available and cheaper medicines than what we have today, and then we must also make sure that we develop medicines. There are more 7 000 rare diseases, we need to do more to ensure that these patients can also obtain available medicines so that they can better live with their disease. Finally, I would like to say that we still have a huge problem of antibiotic resistance, and that is why we need to ensure that our pharmaceutical strategy also makes an effort to secure new business models that enable us to develop medicines in areas where we need it, even though there may not be as much business in it. And then there is no doubt that the whole data strategy can hopefully also help the pharmaceutical industry to ensure better medicines, perhaps with artificial intelligence, etc. So thank you for the strategy, I look forward to working together to get it implemented.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: We are now continuing our debate on the Commission's statement on the EU's pharmaceutical strategy (2020/2878(RSP)."

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, any pharmaceutical strategy must meet two fundamental requirements.  The first requirement: the importance of the public sector, universities and public laboratories in the research and development of vaccines and new drugs, the need to dispute the hegemony of pharmaceutical multinationals, to ensure the primacy of the public interest over the business.  Covid has made particularly visible the perversity of the role given to multinationals in the acquisition of vaccines still in development. With public resources, research is financed, the purchase of vaccines is paid and, in the end, it is still sought to relieve bond companies related to conditions of availability of products and relieve them of risks arising from their use.  The second requirement: the necessary consideration of national strategies that ensure each country's sovereignty in this area, the necessary recognition to each country of the right to produce, of the need to produce, of course, within a framework of necessary international cooperation in this area. This is particularly important in the case of countries such as Portugal, which are very dependent on this area. The right to produce and the pharmaceutical industry cannot be an exclusive only of a few countries.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the sustainability of the healthcare sector is more and more challenging. Moreover, the COVID-19 pandemic has revealed many inefficiencies in our health system and deepened the existing challenges such as shortages. I welcome the proposed EU pharma-strategy. There is a clear and strong signal from the Commission to ensure equitable access to medicines in the EU, both for innovative and generics. Access is uneven in several Member States and sometimes within regions. I also welcome the clear reference to remove excess barriers to generic and biosimilar medicines that is a key milestone also for countries like Romania, but not only. A strong strategy is needed for pharmaceuticals, first to address shortages at the level of manufacturing and supply chains, one that will boost the production as well. And secondly to address the lack of innovation and fuel innovation. With regard to rare diseases and cancers, I would like to echo some of my colleagues’ interventions: there are still too many diseases that have no cure and here, Commissioner, we should ensure that the reopening of the orphan legislation will still support a robust incentives framework for research and innovation. As regards digitalisation, while I welcome the upcoming proposal on the health data space, I’m wondering if the Commission is thinking about introducing digitalisation also at the level of regulatory medicines authorities. Thank you so much and congratulations.

name: César Luena (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this COVID-19 crisis has highlighted the main problems we have. These are problems with prices, relocation and shortages of medicines and medical devices. The first thing I ask you, Commissioner, is that you create a structure. In the Strategy you talk about dialogue, but I believe that it takes a task force, a structure, so that there can be that work between patient associations, between administrations and, also, between the pharmaceutical industry. And I ask you to bet on genuine innovation, not incremental innovation, which is what we've been doing so far and it doesn't solve our problems. We also need to assess the added therapeutic value of innovative new medicines and be R&D benchmarks. I remind you that we have been without new antibiotics for over thirty years, Commissioner. And finally, pointing out that access to advanced therapies cannot be discriminatory. Let's take advantage of this crisis to make a good strategy.

name: Adam Jarubas (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for We welcome the pharmaceutical strategy. The COVID-19 crisis has clearly shown that we need Community mechanisms to supply Europe with effective, safe and affordable medicines in order to mention the COVID vaccine secured by the Union. The pharmaceutical strategy is part of the European Health Union and will benefit from the European Health Programme EU4Health. The European Parliament has tripled the measures proposed by the countries in this programme. This more than five billion euros is twelve times more than the current funding, which was a priority for the European people. A pandemic is not a time for national, party government games [sound disturbance] of the Union budget, measures that can literally save lives. We therefore need regulatory changes and Union support, breaking down economic barriers, accelerating the introduction of new antibiotics, medicines for rare diseases or oncological diseases.  In my region in Poland, for example, the Świętokrzyskie Oncology Centre is counting on it, implementing a very expensive personalized therapy, the cost of which can be reduced sixfold, because today it costs about 400 thousand euros. The Union must regain its drug sovereignty. We need a strategic approach to drug safety, also taken into account by national reimbursement programmes. Jean Monet stressed that the Union is developing not despite crises, but through crises. Today, 66% of EU citizens support an increase in the Union's competences in the area of health. Let us use this to secure the European standard of treatment for all citizens.

name: Romana Jerković (S&D).
text: – Dear Chairman, I congratulate the Commission on the publication of the new European Pharmaceutical Strategy. The pandemic has highlighted a number of problems and raised many questions. One of them is the growing inequality between Member States in the area of quality healthcare. The new Pharmaceutical Strategy is a good basis for the profound changes ahead, but there are aspects that it has not recognized well enough. For example: by 2050 the world's population will rise to 9 billion. It will be difficult to provide adequate health care if health professions and their related disciplines and institutions do not work together, and preventive medicine will be extremely important. I think the strategy must play a much more important role in this aspect, and that it needs to be more actively involved in developing and promoting healthy lifestyle habits rather than being focused solely on the treatment of diseases. Another aspect concerns the impact of climate change on quality of life and health. With the loss of biodiversity, pollution of air and warming of the planet, the number of new infectious diseases is growing. Ignoring the link between climate change and pandemics would be a dangerous misconception.

name: Pernille Weiss (PPE).
text: Mr President! As a bourgeois politician, there is nothing I would rather do than ensure that every human being can live the life they want. I do not have to interfere in whether the soft body has a little extra deller, if the body, by the way, has a happy soul. However, when today we put words to the new pharma strategy, and many of my colleagues very wisely choose to talk about covid, critical security of supply and the crucial importance of making the EU the best place in the world to operate and develop the pharmaceutical industry, Then I choose to draw our attention to the frightening fact that we Europeans are not only getting older and older , fewer and fewer, we are also getting fatter and fatter! More than half of us over the age of 18 are overweight or severely on their way to becoming so. That is many, and as a nurse I will also have to say that it is too many. It's not just ordinary fun that smooths out the wrinkles and signals the enjoyment of life. Obesity is extremely high at risk of developing insulin-dependent diabetes, a very high risk of cancer or one of the other 230 diagnoses affecting people overweight. 2.8 million Europeans die of obesity every year. And I'm sorry to say it, it's also costing the Treasury, it's not going to work. As a citizen, it would be socially and ethically irresponsible if we do not remember that when we are about to go out and roll out the pharma strategy, we must remember the excess weight too, it must be high on the agenda. From digital solutions to our common policies, etc.

name: Łukasz Kohut (S&D).
text: – Mr President, First of all I would like to say that I am not a big fan of widespread government regulation of the economy. In my opinion, markets are far more productive if they are competitive. However, when it comes to critical infrastructure markets, one has to admit that they cannot be left unsupervised. The European market for pharmaceutical products is one such market. The pandemic has proven that it needs more regulation and coordination so that patients receive the best possible access to medicines and medical treatments. For this reason, I welcome the new pharmaceutical strategy, which the Commission adopted yesterday. I especially welcome proposals for actions aimed at increasing the accessibility of medicines for the treatment of childhood cancer or rare diseases. This has not been a priority for producers so far.  I’m looking forward, and committed, to working with the Commission and other actors on the implementation of the strategy in order to achieve higher standards of healthcare and to protect citizens’ well—being.

name: Christophe Hansen (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. As you can see, there is very broad support for your pharmaceutical strategy in this House, and that is a good thing. I would, of course, also like the Member States to be just as optimistic about the matter, because it is also the Member States that have played too little in the past when it comes to common EU health policy. That is quite clear.  However, we must now also state that it will take time for this new strategy to have concrete consequences for our lives in the EU. That is why we must also ensure that what is already in force and enters into force is properly implemented by the Member States. I am the rapporteur for the Drinking Water Directive, which we will be waving through here in the next plenary – the agreement. We have also noted that hormone-active substances need to be looked at more closely. Mrs Ries had already mentioned this. We must try to have more production reintroduction in the European Union. But this will also take time, which is why we need to diversify our supply chains. I would imagine that you would also use a specific fund to help our companies not to be dependent on a single supplier. We have also noted that, at this time, we have had problems, particularly with third countries, where we do not have trade agreements. In other words, we must also adapt our trade policy accordingly, make more trade agreements, because that will help us to become more independent. I am very pleased that Commissioner Dombrovskis is also here – we have the review of trade policy, which is on the agenda. Here too, Mrs Kyriakides, you must intervene so that we can achieve concrete results.

name: Bartosz Arłukowicz (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Europe and the world are fighting COVID-19, and this fight has taught us all that we really have no chance alone with global challenges such as COVID or other challenges and the new struggle we face. This is the fight for cancer patients. Unfortunately, in the coming months, millions of patients with too late-diagnosed cancer will be admitted to European hospitals, often to an advanced degree, probably metastatic and sometimes in a terminal state, because COVID delays treatment, delays diagnoses, delays aid. We therefore need to make a strategic decision today, Commissioner, to build a system of continuity of supply of cancer medicines. Today, we need to build a strategic stockpile of cancer drugs, critical cancer drugs, to help patients.  The second challenge we face today from the COVID experience is to build a smooth emergency and emergency response system. A system must be built to communicate information between governments as quickly as possible and to respond together in the form of buying medicines or securing equipment. These two challenges – europe's strategic stocks of medicines and the crisis response system – are the biggest challenges we face today, the Commissioner and the whole of Europe.

name: Marlene Mortler (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the On Pernille Weiss: As long as you make more money with fat burner tablets than with new antibiotics, something is wrong in the system. Thank you. I very much welcome the European pharmaceutical strategy, because the Corona crisis has shown that we can only make progress together. Our agriculture, for example, is of strategic importance as a sector for our food security. COVID-19 has also shown us the need to ensure robust health and medicines and resilient, diversified supply chains for our citizens. We therefore need, on the one hand, a competitive pharmaceutical industry with an attractive and reliable framework for research, development, regulation and authorisation, and in order to facilitate and accelerate the path to new and innovative therapies and medicines. I am thinking of public, public-private research cooperation with structural and financial support. On the other hand, all patients must receive, without exception, the necessary treatment at an affordable price. It is hoped that the Member States have already made good progress in the joint procurement of vaccines, because we must be better prepared for the next pandemic.

name: Tomislav Sokol (PPE).
text: - Dear Chairman, the Pharmaceutical Strategy for Europe builds on a holistic, patient-centron approach that will ensure the supply of safe and affordable medicines to meet the needs of all patients and ensure the sustainability of health systems.  Drug shortages have been a long-standing problem. A 2019 survey of 24 Member States found that one in four countries do not have a system for reporting shortages of medicines and that their pharmacies have had problems with shortages of medicines. The main challenge is that almost 80% of active ingredients for the production of medicines are imported from third countries. In this regard, I believe that the European Union needs to create conditions and reduce red tape and regulatory barriers in order to bring the pharmaceutical industry as high as possible and enable its development in all parts of the European Union, including those less developed. To do this, European investments through a range of instruments, such as Horizon, THE EU for Health, InvestEU, Digital Europe and cohesion policy in particular, must work synergistically. One of the concrete models of future European cooperation concerns access to innovative medicines. They are not available primarily today because they are expensive. There is a model that would allow for greater availability of expensive medicines, which is a common European public procurement. The math is simple - if the European Union negotiates as a whole, the negotiating position of the Member States is much more favorable, and the final price of medicines for health systems and citizens is cheaper.  It is time to provide lower prices for expensive medicines, primarily for rare diseases and childhood cancers, through joint procurement.

name: Alexander Bernhuber (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The drug strategy is promising, but also long overdue, and the hat is really burning. We in Europe have been struggling with drug shortages for years, and the Commission must show real progress in this. The number of scarce medicines increased more than twenty-fold between 2000 and 2018. More than half of the medicines needed are not available, and patients have to wait a long time for vital cancer drugs and painkillers.  The pandemic has highlighted these appalling grievances even more. There were bottlenecks in protective equipment, medicines were simply not delivered; there is a great need for action here. The problem is that a large proportion of medicines come from abroad. More than 80% of pharmaceutical sprouts come from Asia and 40% of medicines sold in the EU are produced in China or India. For patients, this often means long waiting times, unnecessary additional burdens.  It is very important here and my great appeal is to bring production back to Europe. Billions are being invested in the procurement of medicines, and more must be taken into account in future in the procurement of European medicines. Commissioner, I would ask you to be exemplary in the procurement of COVID vaccines, to pay attention to European production here.  The European supply of medicines is important and must be a major Community objective. It is particularly important here, and I would ask you to take this into account in the pharmaceutical strategy.

name: Stella Kyriakides
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank honourable Members very much for the very inspiring discussion. You have raised a large number of points. I’ll try to cover as much as possible and I’m sure we’ll have many opportunities to discuss this further. First of all, there were questions on the need to revise the rules for rare diseases and children. I want to say that we have already evaluated the legislation on medicines for rare diseases and children. This evaluation has shown that there are already a number of shortcomings. The main problems identified here are insufficient development and in the areas of the greatest unmet medical needs, as I have mentioned. So we will be holding more consultations with stakeholders in the next year and we will be moving forward in order to be able to have a fair and balanced system where we refer to rare diseases and children.  Again, in the same area, there were some questions on how we can push pharmaceutical companies to invest in rare diseases and unmet needs. For example, paediatric cancers appear to be of limited interest for the industry. We need to look at this. Our first step will be to review the legislation on medicines for children and rare diseases. Our objective is simple: to improve the therapeutic landscape and address unmet needs through more tailored incentives. We will foresee the adoption of a new proposal by 2022.  On AMR: there were several questions on antimicrobial resistance. It is a major threat. COVID—19 has further highlighted this. Currently, we see that there’s a weak and challenging business case to invest in the development of new antimicrobials. One of the reasons is that its use must remain restricted once placed on the market. We will be aiming to tackle this in two ways: to measure the reduce and use and ensure the appropriate use of antimicrobials, and also incentivise the development of new classes of antimicrobials. This will be done through both legislative and non-legislative proposals.  Another point that was raised by several of you is access to medicines, a huge issue. This is a key priority. I have said it from the beginning. There can be no first and second-class citizens in the EU. Everyone should have the right of access to the same treatments and the inequalities we see at the moment are simply unacceptable. We need to change this so we will be proposing concrete actions. We will be linking incentives for innovation with obligations for the companies, we will be initiating with the European Medicines Agency (EMA) and Member States a pilot to engage in this, and we will be improving access for generics and biosimilars, which many of you have mentioned. Regarding environmental challenges, the strategy will be addressing the whole lifecycle of pharmaceuticals and we will be proposing to reform our pharma legislation to ensure environmental sustainability, but not only, by also strengthening cooperation with our international partners to ensure quality and environmental sustainability of active pharmaceutical ingredients (APIs) currently imported from non-European countries.  I mentioned generic and biosimilars. This is a very important question because it really can provide patients with access to affordable treatments. We will look to reform the pharma legislation to better promote competition of such products. Regarding affordability, availability of medicines goes hand in hand with affordability so we’ll be promoting and supporting cooperation between national authorities to exchange best practice and will also be looking at improving transparency on the methods for establishing the research and development of medicines. On the issue of data, next year we will be presenting the European health data space. This will aim to facilitate access and the exchange of health data. This would really change the way that health systems and patient access are being seen at the moment. But we do need to understand that health data is also very sensitive so we need to ensure a high level of protection. We will be engaging closely with citizens to make sure that they can understand this. In terms of the production of medicinal products and because I have mentioned strategic autonomy and there were some questions on this, I want to be absolutely clear that the EU will remain open and promote open trade. Protectionism is not in the DNA of the European Union, but strategic economy is a political objective of this strategy and it’s also a major lesson learned from COVID—19. But, first of all, we need to have a better understanding of the supply chain design and identify its vulnerability in order to be able to move forward, while continuing to diversify our supply sources, wherever necessary manufacturing in Europe, and working more closely with our third—country trading partners. Trade came up again when we were discussing the security of supply. We are exploring, in the context of the World Trade Organization, the launching of an initiative facilitating trade in health products in emergency situations and also looking at how we can explore with the EU’s trading partners to conclude a multilateral agreement on tariff elimination on pharmaceutical and medical goods. Regarding intellectual property and the pharmaceutical strategy, I will try to be very brief. Any revisions to the rules of intellectual property and pharmaceutical investment incentives will address the need to foster innovation and make medicines available to all patients at an affordable price. So innovation needs to match the needs and match the needs of patients.  We have already addressed shortages, but what we need to understand is that what we all need to work on together is to ensure that medicines are available to patients in need and at all times, whether it is a time of crisis or not. The patient is really at the heart of this initiative. Because the causes of medicine shortages are complex, before moving forward we have launched a study on the root causes of medicine shortages. This will be finalised in the second half of 2021 and we will then be able to promote specific actions.  Regarding what we done in the last few months – because there were several questions on that – to address it, I won’t list all the actions, but I can say that, from the very beginning of this pandemic, I personally, and with Commissioner Breton, have engaged with industry, asking them to increase production capacity where we identified increased demand. We adopted guidelines to promote optimal supply of medicines and we launched joint procurement to address shortages of critical hospital medicines. So a great deal has been done, but we need to put this into place so that, at a time of crisis, we already have everything in place that we need to have. Regarding innovation, this is really one of the things at the heart of the pharmaceutical legislation proposals and we need to make the necessary adaptations in order for our legislation to be really more innovation friendly. This will also deal with bottlenecks and improve regulatory gaps that we may have. We need to give incentives to industry, but we also expect accessibility to medicines to be improved and inequalities of access to disappear from the EU. There were one or two questions on cancer. The Europe Beating Cancer Plan is shortly going to be presented before you, but we know that cancer is a major cause of death in children after infancy and so we are looking at the revision of the Orphan and Paediatric Regulation to ensure this. We need to do more in the treatment of paediatric cancers and this pharmaceutical strategy will interact very closely with the Europe Beating Cancer Plan because it will support the goal of sustainable cancer prevention with the right incentives for innovation, for a vaccination against treatable infections that cause cancer and much more. And, yes, we propose to amend the role of the European Medicines Agency (EMA). I have already analysed this when presenting the European health union. I have absolutely no doubt that this is the way forward for a stronger European health union. We will need to strengthen our agencies in order for them to deliver what we expect them to deliver. I’d like to end by answering what several honourable Members mentioned on the issue of competencies. We are very well aware of the competencies, as of course is the European Parliament and the Council, but we’re also very well aware of the importance of solidarity and coordination. Everything we have put forward, in terms of the European health union and in terms of the pharmaceutical strategy, takes into account and is well within the Treaty. But we have also learned from COVID—19 that we need to be flexible and we need to try and work, using the Treaty, to all the limits that it can give us and all the boundaries so that we can move forward. I very much look forward to your support for this strategy. We need to have the support of the European Parliament. I want to thank you on a personal basis, because I’ve had the opportunity to speak with many of you over the last few months, for the support for EU for health and the increase in the budget. This is a very important part for us.  What I can end by saying is that, with President von der Leyen and with all my colleagues, all the Commissioners, we are going to leave no stone unturned until we find the way out of this pandemic. We need to seize the opportunity of this crisis to come out stronger, stronger in the area of health, and deliver to citizens what they expect – a stronger European health union. This is what they have asked us for from the beginning of this crisis and this is what we should all be working together to deliver.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Nicolás González Casares (S&D)
text: in writing. – The adoption of the Pharmaceutical Strategy for Europe is undoubtedly a step forward in the construction of a European Health Union.  The S&D Group has long demanded further action to ensure access to safe, effective and affordable medicines, and welcomes the fact that the proposal put forward by the Commission suggests concrete action to achieve these objectives.  The Spanish Socialists hope that the Commission will create a structure in which there can be a joint work of patient associations, administrations and the pharmaceutical industry. In addition, we call for greater investment in genuine, non-incremental research that assesses the added therapeutic value of innovative new medicines and makes the EU a therapeutic benchmark in R&D.  The COVID-19 pandemic should serve as a lesson in creating a good pharmaceutical strategy. Future measures should focus on patients, ensuring equal access to medicines and therapies for all European citizens. The ultimate goal is to ensure the health of all and build a europe that is more resilient to future health crises.

name: Javi López (S&D)

In addition, we call for greater investment in genuine, non-incremental research that assesses the added therapeutic value of innovative new medicines and makes the EU a therapeutic benchmark in R&D.  The COVID-19 pandemic should serve as a lesson in creating a good pharmaceutical strategy. Future measures should focus on patients, ensuring equal access to medicines and therapies for all European citizens. The ultimate goal is to ensure the health of all and build a europe that is more resilient to future health crises.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE)
text: in writing. – We have an obligation to guarantee citizens equal access to medicines. Medicines must be affordable for everyone, not missing from pharmacies, not having to replace new and more effective medicines with old ones, because of prohibitive prices, or to find out that for rare diseases there are no medicines just because, by their nature, they are not profitable for pharmaceutical companies.  The European Commission presented us in this plenary session, the new pharmaceutical strategy. A move that I welcome to apply to other health programmes, such as the 'EU for Health' or the future European Cancer Plan. Both are ambitious programmes with salutary goals. However, if we fail to give people an essential right such as access to the medicines they need, then all these objectives will remain on paper.  The new pharmaceutical strategy must guarantee: equal access to medicines, affordable prices for innovative medicines, their availability in all Member States, medicines accessible for rare diseases, transparency of the costs of developing a new medicine, eu pharmaceutical independence by relocating the production of basic substances, even if the costs of pharmaceutical companies by labour will increase. In addressing the new pharmaceutical strategy, we need to stop looking at medicines as commercial goods and consider them existential goods.

name: Edina Tóth (PPE)
text: Writing. – The global coronavirus and an ageing European society have shown that Member States are facing a growing health risk, which is also a much greater burden on society. The fact that the supply chain of medicines is becoming increasingly rigid today, the share of the European pharmaceutical industry is declining and European health is extremely dependent on third-country production and imports. This makes it vulnerable in some areas, which in severe cases can even lead to a shortage of medicines. At the same time, it is important to point out that the pharmaceutical industry is not comparable to other industries and medicines cannot be compared to other commodities. Supply disruptions have a much better impact on people's lives and quality of life than other products. That is why I consider the European Pharmaceutical Strategy to be extremely important, which, if properly carried out, could provide the European Union with a unique opportunity to strengthen Europe's role in its global pharmaceutical production. Although there are still many questions and missing information on the strategy, we have good reason to support efforts to achieve the objectives of the strategy and to strengthen the European pharmaceutical industry.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on Bernd Lange's report on behalf of the Committee on International Trade on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the abolition of tariffs on certain products (COM(2020)0496 – C9-0284/2020 - 2020/0253 (COD)) (A9-0217/2020). I would point out to Members that all the debates in this part-session do not include spontaneous speeches and that no blue cards are accepted. I know that this also leads to resentment, but it is also a question of justice that this line should be crossed. Mr Martusciello was very annoyed earlier that I did not give him the floor, even though he wanted to comment on the passing of Diego Maradona. But the rule applies to everyone. It also provides for interconnection from Parliament's liaison offices in the Member States.

name: Bernd Lange
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has In recent weeks, our knowledge of geography about the United States has grown significantly. Now we know exactly where Georgia is, and also where Maine is: that's up there on the map of the United States. In Maine, in fact, is the place where the most American lobster is produced.  That is what the legislation we have on the table is all about. Because the American lobster industry has suffered greatly from what Mr. Trump has instigated in trade wars, especially with regard to China: 25% extra tariff on American lobsters. But we, too, have concluded a trade agreement with Canada – CETA – that also allows Canadian lobsters into the European Union duty-free, so that we are also in competition with Maine there, so that demand in Maine has fallen by 50%. This is, of course, dramatic, and in this respect I think it is right that we should say here that we are giving you an offer and we are also allowing American lobsters into the European Union duty-free.  This is not a primordial social democratic demand – duty-free for lobsters – but in the INTA, the Socialist Group, like many others, has accepted this proposal by a large, overwhelming majority, for two reasons: the one reason is that this is an MFN story, that applies to all lobster producers, so it is not a unilateral measure, as Mr Trump would have liked, but a universal one. Producers from, for example, Honduras or Nicaragua now have this duty-free regime, and it may also be an opportunity for other producers.
