The second thing, Mr President and Commissioner, is, of course, that this is an offer – an offer to tackle the many construction sites that we have with the United States. I would just like to mention eight very briefly: there are the national security investigations, the 232 tariffs that Mr Trump has imposed on steel, on aluminium, on the threat of cars, on port cranes, on energy lines – all of this needs to be put to the test and whether this is really still up-to-date. And if there are conflicts, we can go to the WTO.  The tariffs imposed under 301 in the area of unfair trade practices have also, of course, been a foreclosure measure. The debate that is currently taking place is, of course, the question of measures against a digital tax, which is being discussed very intensively in France, but also within the European Union. Even if there are conflicts here, it is appropriate to discuss this within the framework of the WTO and not with countermeasures of individual customs settlements. We also need to talk to each other in the area of so-called anti-dumping duties on aluminium products. It is not acceptable to think that 18 countries around the world – very different companies – have now gone and agreed: now we are dumping so that we have access to the American market. That is not fair either, and we must also talk about it with each other.  Then we have had the Airbus-Boeing discussion – for 16 years. That's escalating a little bit higher now. We have to get on with it, we have to sit down and see how we find a balance, how we find compliance, how we also make sure that third-party aircraft providers fit into this set of rules as well. Ladies and gentlemen, legislation in the United States called 'energy security for Europe' is, of course, a little strange. We would not, after all, come up with the idea of passing legislation called 'energy security for the United States'. What is involved is the sanctioning of European companies. We must also discuss and repeal this.  Of course, we also have common interests, for example in dealing with China. But here too, I believe, it is a question of acting together, of sitting down, of developing a common strategy and of not taking unilateral, unilateral measures any more.  Within the framework of the WTO, too, we finally need a reform of the arbitral tribunal, the Appellate Body. We need the blockade for the new Director-General of the WTO to be lifted, and we need an extension of the WTO rule book. Here, too, we can cooperate – as well as in the area of the protection of the Paris climate agreement, implementation, and also workers' rights. I am very pleased that my colleague, Mr Neal, the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, has made it clear in Congress that trade policy should now be made more worker-friendly.  In this respect, it is clear, ladies and gentlemen, that divergences will remain. But we now have the chance to sit down and see how we can move forward together. And there are, in fact, more similarities than can sometimes be seen in concrete disputes. In this respect, this law is an offer. And the motto is not "lobster for all", but the motto is "cooperation instead of confrontation".

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Executive Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, the proposed regulation under discussion today is of high political importance for improving the transatlantic trade relationship. As you know, the EU and the US have the largest bilateral trade and investment relationship and the most integrated economic relationship in the world. This relationship has, however, been under considerable strain in recent years, with increased areas of tension, and with US unilateral actions leading to a negative impact on bilateral trade.  This package helps to set us on a better path. It is the first negotiated reduction of duties between us in more than two decades. While it is limited in scope, it is an important sign of our joint wish to de—escalate tensions. It can support settlement of other ongoing disputes and help us to engage on a positive agenda.  It is in this context and spirit that the then EU Commissioner for Trade Hogan and US Trade Representative Lighthizer issued a joint statement in August of this year to announce a package of tariff reductions. Since then, we have worked hard to make it into reality and the EU and US should now adopt the necessary autonomous measures under their domestic procedures and legislative scrutiny to realise the objectives of the joint statement, starting with a tariff reduction package. This is the aim of the proposed regulation in front of you. In substance, the proposed regulation stipulates that the EU will eliminate import tariffs on certain types of lobster. The US, on its side, will provide a 50% duty relief for a comparable economic value on products such as prepared meals, certain crystal glassware, surface preparations, propellant powders, cigarette lighters and lighter parts. The tariff reductions are to be implemented in a fully WTO—consistent manner, respecting the Most Favoured Nation principle. They are to apply for an initial period of five years, retroactively beginning on 1 August 2020.  The objective of the joint statement is to de—escalate tensions, but this can be only fulfilled in a context where the US does not carry out the threats they have been making in recent years to impose certain measures on the EU, including unilateral tariffs under Section 232 and Section 301 outside the WTO framework. The proposed regulation therefore provides that if the US does not reduce its own tariffs or it introduces new measures against the EU that undermine the objectives of the joint statement, the Commission may suspend the elimination of duties provided for in the regulation. On 10 November, the Committee on International Trade voted favourably on the adoption of the regulation, without amendments. Also, the Council endorsed the Commission proposal following a Coreper on 18 November, and it has indicated that if the European Parliament adopts the Commission’s proposal at first reading it would approve its position and the regulation should be adopted accordingly.  So we are very encouraged by this. We see this regulation as the right step at the right time. It allows us to signal to the incoming US administration our strong commitment to transatlantic trade relationships. I am looking forward to hearing your views today and hope for a positive outcome of the discussion.

name: Danuta Maria Hübner
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, first of all I would like to thank the Commission for its tireless work towards a positive transatlantic trade agenda despite the difficult circumstances in those years of dysfunctional trade relations. As Vice-President Dombrovskis said, this agreement brings mutual lowering of the tariffs by both sides for the first time in 20 years and as part of the escalating strategy it can be a stepping stone toward more vigorous engagement in an open and frank discussion about further reduction of trade irritants in transatlantic relations. There are still many of those and Bernd Lange mentioned many of them.  We have to find a negotiated solution regarding subsidies to our airline industries, but we also have to engage effectively in multilateral fora to promote a fair and rules-based global trading system. The US is our obvious strategic partner in a shifting global landscape and trade is a crucial instrument of this strategic partnership. Our trade relations will most likely not go back to good old times with the election of Joe Biden, but the new President is a transatlanticist and it gives me hope that we can approach common challenges with a fresh start. The vote in the Committee on International Trade on the agreement with an overwhelming majority shows that we appreciate a constructive approach to the transatlantic relationship and I hope that with a similar majority in the plenary vote we can send the signal to the incoming administration that the EU is ready and willing to jointly build a future based on common, strategic and systemic interests.

name: Pedro Silva Pereira
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, this proposal to eliminate customs duties on certain products is not what it seems. In itself, despite its universal application, as our rapporteur Bernd Lange recalled, this proposal reflects a 'mini commercial agreement' with the United States which benefits only a few products. It does not reach EUR 200 million when we have a total flow of trade of around EUR 800 billion today.  Of course, reducing tariffs or eliminating tariffs is always positive for the sectors involved, whether it is european products that will be exported at the most competitive prices, whether it is the live or frozen lobster industry, which will benefit from exports from the United States to the European Union free of tariffs.  But the truth is that this understanding is a first step towards restoring normality in trade relations between the European Union and the United States and that is what we really want: to end this absurd trade war, which we can only do by restoring bonds of trust and taking steps in the right direction, and this is a step in the right direction.  We really want to put an end to an absurd war, which has no winners and benefits no one, and we want to re-establish our transatlantic relationship, for the sake of the economy, for the sake of the global trade order, but above all for the sake of peace and security, for the sake of multilateralism and for the sake of development cooperation.

name: Liesje Schreinemacher
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, ‘the growth of the Euro-Atlantic community has turned out to be one of the greatest forces in human history for advancing peace, prosperity, security and democracy.’ This is a direct quote of Vice-President Biden back in 2014 and I couldn’t agree with him more. So let’s put these great words into action and let’s rebuild our transatlantic relationship, a relationship based on our common values and objectives, with a United States that believes in multilateralism and wants to tackle global challenges together. A United States that wishes to preserve rules-based trade and fight climate change.  The tariff reduction deal or the so-called ‘lobster deal’ that we are discussing today is a positive step towards these better transatlantic trade relations. It is the first deal of its kind between the European Union and the United States for 20 years, and even though the scope is limited I believe it is a strong political signal from our side that we want to do business with our American friends.  But like any friendship we should also be frank with each other. So let us be very clear that the times of punitive tariffs are over. We have been turning the other cheek for too long. I hope we can stop the additional tariffs on each other’s products and that the new Administration also understands that there is no sense in punishing our Gouda cheese, meat or wine producers, which in turn forces us to hit American cheddar, ketchup and chocolate producers with the same tariffs.  In conclusion, this tariff reduction deal that we are voting on here today is important. Instead of introducing new tariffs we are removing them. It is high time for a constructive approach. We now have the possibility to strengthen our transatlantic trade relationship for the benefit of our citizens and our businesses. I invite the new Biden Administration to join us in these ambitions.

name: Maximilian Krah
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Lange, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. First of all, yes, that is good news that we are succeeding in setting at least one symbol in one area that trade relations with the United States will continue. The fact that it is now lobster, of all places, may confirm some prejudices about the EU. But we also want to talk about a symbol, so the Commission is allowed to do so. However, I believe that when we talk about trade relations with the United States, we can also look a little further. It has already been said that this is the first agreement in 20 years, and that relates to lobster. However, we should note that elsewhere in the world, and only recently in Bangkok, the largest free trade agreement of our time has been concluded – with almost all Asian countries. In other words, we see that in the 21st century we have a movement that is moving, that economic development, but also technological development, is moving from the Atlantic to the Asian sphere. The question we have to ask ourselves in the European Union – in each individual Member State – is whether we want to benefit from whether we want to participate, or whether we want to remain in the categories of the late 20th century. So do we want to be part of a trade war against development in Asia, or do we not want to use this development in Asia to ensure long-term prosperity and technical development? That is why, in all trade relations with the United States, we must also ask critical questions and not say: how wonderful that Mr Biden now wants to re-enter transatlantic politics and that he has said that he is ready to lead the world. The world should be led by people where they live. Europeans should lead Europe themselves, and they should, for example, determine their own energy security. I find a statement that says 'I am ready to lead the world when the American Congress passes a european energy security law' as a threat rather than a promise.  That is why I am in favour of sending a signal to the United States here, but I would warn against now believing that, because of a new free trade debate with the United States, we must now completely separate ourselves from Asia and Russia. The truth is that sovereign in the 21st century is the one who has alternatives. The main industrial and commercial goods of the 21st century are technology and energy. What we are seeing is that the United States is currently putting pressure on European states and the EU – contrary to international law through sanctions on third countries – so that they can decide where we get our energy from – from them, through liquefied natural gas – and that they decide where we get our technology from – not in China. We do not want that, we cannot accept that. Even if we reject Nordstream 2, and even if we have concerns about Huawei, the decision must be made by us, not by the US Congress. Otherwise, we can get rid of ourselves here. That is why I welcome this decision on lobster, even though I eat less of it than perhaps the Social Democrats. But I warn against thinking now that we must now fall back into the political categories of the 1980s – the Cold War. Juhu, finally we're got rid of Trump! What is coming now will be much worse in terms of our trade relations to the east – Russia, India, China – than what Trump was, and that has already been announced. In this respect, I would ask you, Mr Lange – and I have indeed full confidence in you – to continue to look in both directions and to get the maximum out of us. We want to benefit from the 21st century, and this development, it does not take place in the West, but is taking place even more strongly – and we have seen this since the Bangkok trade agreement – in the east.

name: Reinhard Bütikofer
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, with the so—called ‘lobster’ trade deal between the EU and the United States that reduces some tariffs on either side, we open a door to shared efforts to overcome the trade war mentality which has poisoned transatlantic relations over the last four years.  The deal is a fair and a balanced one. We’re not naive. That’s why we have also put two guardians at the door. One is the trade enforcement mechanism that we have put in place, the other is the retaliating tariffs, which we have legally imposed on the WTO rules to signal to the US that there is a need for an agreement in the age-old Boeing-Airbus battles. As we do open a door, we also emphasise that our efforts cannot be successful if this were to be a one-way traffic. Both sides have to be willing to go through this door. We expect the new Biden Administration to understand this.  Low-hanging fruits will be an agreement on the new WTO Director-General, new efforts – shared efforts – to reform the WTO appellate body and overcoming the Boeing-Airbus mess. We’re willing to engage in broader shared efforts: WTO reform in general, lifting unfair sanctions on EU steel and aluminium, developing effective ways of greening trade rules in order to live up to the challenge of climate change. Let us revive trade multilateralism and modernise it at the same time.  By the way, as Mr Lange said, this deal is also an opportunity for other countries because it’s organised under the MFN (most-favoured-nation) rule. It’s a multilateral solution, it doesn’t only help Maine’s lobster industry, that is suffering under the consequences of Trump’s trade war, but it can also help Australian producers that suffer under Chinese coercive measures. We support this deal and we hope for more to come.

name: Geert Bourgeois
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, this lobster agreement comes at the right time, not only for the fishermen of Maine in the USA and other countries, but also because of its political importance.  It's time to put four years of friction, four years of conflict, four years of threats behind us. I think, Mr Vice-President, that we need to work on a renewed partnership with the US: not just to resolve the conflicts – the unilateral measures for aluminium and steel, the Boeing/Airbus issue, the carbon correction mechanism at the border – but to look ahead, sit down together at the table.  I know that with this new President it may also be too much to come up with a comprehensive trade agreement – president Biden is also in favour of the buy American slogan – but I think and I hope that you will take the thread back from the Juncker/Trump agreement, which your predecessor also worked on, and at least come to a small agreement.  On multilateralism, too, we must join forces, save the WTO, make the WTO operational, modernise the WTO, reform it.  I ask you: work with the US on multilateralism, work out of equal worth of a transatlantic partnership, try to set the standard together globally together.  And tell your American friends, tell Mr. Biden, that in this new geopolitical world order, America can only be back together with its allies, together with the European Union.

name: Emmanuel Maurel
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Madam President, I understand the enthusiasm of some colleagues, but let me tell you that I do not really share it. So yes, it is true, this is the first tariff concession agreement with the United States in almost 20 years. And yes, indeed, our debate comes at a time when Joe Biden won the presidential election and some of us are hopeful, not least because Biden has announced that he will ratify the Paris agreement. For us, this is good news. But at the same time, if there is one area, in my opinion, where U.S. policy is not going to change, it is trade policy, because aggressiveness in this area did not begin with Mr. Trump and, in my opinion, it will survive the Trump administration. I would like to remind our enthusiastic colleagues that the signing of this agreement has not prevented the United States from introducing new restrictions on the import of steel and aluminum under the WTO's anti-dumping regime. I would also like to point out that the United States continues to aggressively resort to extraterritorial measures against European companies, hence the need to continue to be vigilant, determined, not naïve. This is what Canadians are doing, for example, who have understood that, in order to roll back the Americans, they must be confronted with swift retaliatory measures. You say cooperation and not confrontation, but the Americans should be prepared for cooperation. That is not the case today. So let's stay vigilant, stay engaged. A word, a thought, because there is a lot of talk about the fishermen in Maine, but I am thinking of the Breton and Irish fishermen at the time of the Brexit negotiations, who are also fishing for lobster and who are also facing difficult economic conditions.

name: Daniel Caspary (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Almost ten years ago, the TTIP negotiations began at that time, and many still have the phrase in mind when the American Trade Representative said that we would conclude these negotiations with a single tank. Then came the situation very quickly that many people were worried in Europe. Sometimes there was a conscious mood; it was about the allegedly dangerous chlorine chickens, it was about supposedly planned lowering standards, there were scattered half-truths, untruths and fake news. What was exciting was when President Trump came to power and we saw transatlantic trade relations and transatlantic relations in general reaching a low point. There were many of those who shouted the loudest against the TTIP agreement at the time, those who shouted the loudest: 'Yes, we would have an agreement with the United States and we would be set up accordingly!' That is why I would like us to take advantage of this slow in-journey. We concluded the agreement on high-quality beef last year, and this year the agreement on lobster. We have many construction sites – Bernd Lange has mentioned some, such as the Airbus/Boeing dispute, the arbitrary tariffs on steel and aluminium – but we all face the challenge: the big competitor is in China; this is a systemic issue between democracies and market economies and this communist system. I hope that we all have the strength to make compromises with the Americans and then to jointly assert common interests throughout the world, always knowing that there are, of course, areas where we have different interests.

name: Kathleen Van Brempt (S&D).
text: Mr President, I am not going to talk about lobster. Lobster and champagne, that is a difficult subject for socialists. But rest assured, I welcome this deal. I think we should approve him, too.  We all know that the United States is our most important trading partner. At the same time, we have seen enormous pressure on these trade relations in recent years. And so it's time to start working on a positive story with the United States when it comes to multilateral relations and trade relations.  But I want to make one thing very clear. Unfortunately, the United States was also the first country to withdraw from the Paris agreement in recent years. And – irony, o irony – since 4 November they are not really bound by that agreement anymore. Going back to the Paris agreement must be a prerequisite for the European Union to further develop these positive trade relations. The Biden administration has committed to that. That's very important, positive news.  It is also important to work on these positive trade relations together with the agenda that we ourselves have put forward within the Green New Deal. The carbon correction at the border, for example, will be an incredibly important subject to work on, but also the digital tax, which we are going to need to get our own recovery right. We must also be able to make good agreements with the United States on this.  To conclude: yes, we are going to support and approve this agreement, but it must be a first step towards working towards a sustainable future and to working on trade relations that should ensure that in the future we can get out of this pandemic around the world and thus write a positive story.

name: Marie-Pierre Vedrenne (Renew).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I must admit that the election of Joe Biden and his desire to re-enter the Paris Agreement is a game-changer, because no trade agreement, even limited, can be signed with a non-Paris Agreement. Compatibility with our WTO commitments, the rules of the most favoured integrated nation: that is a good thing. The conditionality clause also. For, let us be clear, if the United States introduces new illegal measures, the Commission will have to react. This mini-deal has its use, but must be the exception. Trade policy is not just about tariff liberalization, but it must go hand in hand with the promotion of human rights and the fight against climate change. So the election of a Democrat to the White House suggests that the defender of multilateralism will return to the negotiating table. However, this return does not bode well for the outcome of our exchanges. So let's not kid ourselves, we can't expect everything from the United States and become the playground of the China-U.S. conflict. The European Union must defend trade based on rules, rules adapted and respected by all. Many disputes remain, such as the extraterritoriality of U.S. laws that harm the interests of European businesses and citizens. Let us increase our capacity to react to the excesses of extraterritoriality. We don't want a trade war, we want the conditions for peace. So we will support this first agreement as a basis for cooperation, but make no mistake, our strategic autonomy must be our horizon and priority.

name: Danilo Oscar Lancini (ID).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the true meaning of this agreement is political more than commercial, as we all know. We must aim to improve relations with the United States, easing trade tensions and supporting a fair resolution of ongoing disputes. The UNITED States is the EU's leading market for agricultural and food products, it is the most important destination for the export of high value added products. As you know, the dispute over Airbus and Boeing subsidies has led to tariff increases on many European products exported to the United States. These increases have affected products from countries that do not participate in the Airbus consortium and sectors that are not involved in the dispute, such as agri-food, where European products are already penalised by imports that do not comply with our own rules. In view of the recent ruling by the World Trade Organisation, which authorised Europe to apply duties on US products and services of EUR 4 billion, it is all the more necessary to engage in constructive dialogue and avoid any kind of escalation that would have unforeseeable and worrying effects at a particularly sensitive time for the economy due to the effects of the pandemic. I would remind you that, also in the agri-food sector, six years ago it was the victim of Russian counter-sanctions in response to European support for the United States on sanctions against the Russian Federation, with a total loss to 2017 of the European agricultural sector and food industry of around 5.5 billion euros and damage reported to the made in Italy agri-food sector of about one billion euros by 2020. To this are added the onerous commitments in terms of sustainability that farmers could ... (The President cut the speaker off) ... be called upon to comply with the next Community rules.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, as the Commissioner has said, the European Union and the United States have the largest bilateral trading fraction and the most integrated  economic relationship in the world. But unfortunately, under President Trump, who had a more frosty approach to the European Union, our trading relationship has been strained, and when the US imposed tariffs on our steel and aluminium on alleged national security grounds, naturally the EU retaliated. However, this deal marks the first time in more than 20 years that the US and the EU decided to cut tariffs, marking critical  de-escalation in transatlantic relations. This is something that Commissioner Hogan should be given great credit for. Having discussed details of the deal with him, I know how he used his political skills, his experience and his Irishness to thaw the frost, if I may use that phrase. However, with a Joe Biden presidency, we’re likely to see a more multilateral approach and cooperation on such things as climate change, prevention of future pandemics, open trade environment, all this is very positive.  Now, of course, we have to monitor the effects of this agreement on European fishermen and especially ensure that no harm is done to the bio-security of our native lobster stocks. This should include financial assistance from the EU and, if necessary, a price monitoring of native lobster stocks. I would ask the Commissioner, is this part of the plan?  Overall, this is a good deal and I welcome it and look forward to better relations between ourselves and the US in due course.

name: Agnes Jongerius (S&D).
text: Mr President, waking up in a strange world! What's going on here? More than two years ago, I expressed my surprise at the row between Donald Trump and Jean-Claude Juncker as two kemphanen. They were diametrically opposed in the fight over steel import tariffs. Unfortunately, it became a long series of conflicts – from allegations of alleged state aid to aircraft manufacturers to blocking tech taxes for the Googles of this world. And indeed, the impossible became possible: the United States and Europe were diametrically opposed.  What does that world look like now? The us election was won by Democrat Joe Biden. This gives hope for better relations and a stable relationship with mutual respect. This mini-deal today is a welcome first step. Hopefully, it will lead to a reduction in trade tensions and the resolution of the conflicts. This is necessary, because it is indecent that multinationals pay hardly any tax while the baker on the corner does. And it is incomprehensible that in times of global warming, the Americans have withdrawn from the Paris Climate Agreement. But moreover, we desperately need each other in the fight for fair trade around the world, trade that takes into account, for example, the signing of the ILO conventions, so that workers everywhere in the world are assured of good working conditions. Mr President, we are not there yet, but we are on our way. The new change of power in the US represents new hope to restore our decades-long good trade relations.

name: Jordi Cañas (Renew).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, this 'mini-agreement' is a small step at the commercial level, but it is a major step at the political level in advancing the normalisation of trade relations with the United States. However, it shows a marked lack and deficiency at the level of our trade policy. The lack is obvious: there is a lack of coherence. Why? Because, while this Commission slows down and paralyzes the agreement with Mercosur, because it doubts the environmental commitments of countries signing the Paris Agreements, it negotiates a trade agreement with a country that has directly abandoned them, as is the case with the United States. So is respect for the Paris Agreements a sine qua non condition when it comes to Mercosur, but not when it comes to the United States? Inconsistency. The shortcoming: this agreement is a missed opportunity to correct an unfair situation for European products suffering unilateral tariffs by the United States, as is the case with Spanish table olives since 2017. Commissioner, Europe needs trade, rules-based trade, committed to environmental protection, sustainable development and human rights. But these values must be applicable and enforceable to all of our partners equally. It also needs the Commission to defend all European products equally, not only aluminium and steel, but also olives. Because launching conflicting messages with asymmetric demands depending on who is negotiated seriously undermines and threatens the European Union's international credibility. Just as not defending all European products equally undermines and threatens that of citizens in their institutions. Finally, the longing for a geopolitical Europe, especially in the commercial sphere, needs momentum, leadership and commitment, but especially equity and coherence.

name: Angelo Ciocca (ID).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, from milan we tell what the League has been telling for years and we are pleased that the European Parliament is finally talking about duties and understands the importance of duties. Tariffs are a means of regulating markets where there is unfair competition. If there are countries that have different rules than our producers, the duty becomes a means of avoiding so-called dumping, of avoiding unfair competition. Europe must do this. In addition to doing this, it must also maintain controls on products coming from outside Europe, because it is the European Food Safety Authority itself which certifies that the products arriving in Europe are eight times more dangerous than those from Italy and Europe, especially those arriving from China and especially those from China which , often, they have inside insecticides banned for years by our laws. I understand that perhaps in China they use insecticides to kill and eat insects, but in Europe this must not happen. It is clear that Germany, with 48 % of its exports, has advantages, but it cannot be thought that for the benefit of one country the other twenty-six countries are invading themselves with products from outside Europe.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE).
text: – Madam President, last Tuesday we discussed here the guidelines to be followed by our common trade policy and strongly demanded that the Commission develop its economic sovereignty and strategic autonomy. Today we welcome this customs duty elimination agreement to a number of products, not so much because of the figures — a small tariff line of just EUR 168 million — but for what it represents politically, because it is the first in twenty years between the European Union and the United States and because it must mean the start of transatlantic tariff de-escalation. Also because a new stage opens up in our relations with the United States after the election, and many of us hope that from now on there will be a real political will to regard the European Union not as a commercial rival but as a geopolitical ally. It is clear that we remain immersed in tariff battles that continue to penalize agri-food products from across the European Union, and especially key Spanish sectors such as olive oil, wine, table olives or cheese. And it is our producers who continue to suffer unfairly the consequences of disputes that are alien to them. And this must stop. The European Union and the United States necessarily have to understand each other, and for this we must be dialogue, but also firm in defending our interests. I know balances aren't easy. Today's is a good start.

name: Valdis Dombrovskis
text: Executive Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all, thank you for your observations and for the useful debate today. Your support to adopt the proposed regulation rapidly will help to send a strong political signal of improving transatlantic trade relationships. This will prepare the ground for a positive start with the new US administration and can lead the way forward towards additional positive steps and agreements. So, with your support, we will take this important step on the road to a stronger transatlantic trade relationship.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place today, Thursday 26 November. Before we move on to the debate on cases of violations of human rights, democracy and the rule of law, I would like to inform you that the President of Mrs Assita Kanko has received a request for a comment on the application of the Rules of Procedure under Rule 39.

name: Assita Kanko (ECR).
text: – Madam President, I would like to raise a point of order under Rule 39, given that under Rule 144 it was not possible to raise this urgent matter. In the last couple of days, there have been alarming reports that EU citizen Ahmad Reza Jalali has been transferred to solitary confinement by the Iranian authorities in preparation for his execution in the coming week. This deserves the urgent and utmost attention of the European Union.  I call upon the European Parliament President, on High Representative Borrell and EU Foreign Ministers to urge the Iranian authorities to review this decision, not to execute Doctor Jalali, and to agree to his release. If Iran does not agree to this, then the EU must look to sanctions. This is very urgent.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on the deterioration of the human rights situation in Algeria, in particular the case of journalist Khaled Drareni (2020/2880(RSP)). I would like to point out once again that no spontaneous speeches or blue cards are accepted in all the debates of this part-session. It also provides for interconnection from Parliament's liaison offices in the Member States.

name: Marisa Matias
text: Author. – Madam President, the situation in Algeria and the permanent tensions are not now. We have seen continuous mobilisation by citizens who want to end the authoritarian regime.  In this resolution, we send a message of solidarity to all those in Algeria who seek to fight for human rights. We condemn arbitrary and illegal detentions, including the detention of journalists, human rights defenders and peaceful opponents. We ask that the sentences be abandoned against all prisoners of conscience, including Khaled Drareni. We support the feminist movement's claims for equality. We reaffirm that the activities of European companies must be carried out in the fulfilment of the protection of human rights and against any form of exploitation. As one of the leaders of the Iraq movement said, the resistance movement, "in words dialogue, on the ground repression". In Algeria, repression is taking place. We need to stand by the dialogue.

name: Salima Yenbou
text: Author. Madam President, at the beginning of 2019 an extraordinary and peaceful social movement - the Hirak - was born in Algeria, which calls for a freer, more egalitarian and transparent society, as well as a better future for Algeria and Algerian youth. The Hirak is a new movement, extraordinary and even exemplary, characterized by the total absence of violence during the demonstrations over a very long time and by this Algerian humor so special. Algerians can be proud of this. The press that relayed this movement was unfortunately targeted for this. Algeria's renewal cannot be done by flouting press freedom, including using the health crisis to increase its repression. Ensuring freedom of the press means ensuring the vitality of our democracies, the flow of information, open-mindedness, critical thinking, creativity and citizen awakening. In 2020, Algeria is ranked 146th (out of 180) in the world press freedom ranking, falling by 27 places compared to 2015. Through this resolution, we want to show the Algerian people and human rights defenders that we do not forget them and show them our solidarity and support. Second, ask the government to respect the fundamental freedom to inform and inform. They also call on the European Commission and the EEAS to adopt a stronger public position on respect for human rights in Algeria, to do everything in their power to convince the Algerian authorities to stop arbitrary detentions and to inform us regularly of developments. Finally, to end on a note of hope, to dream and work to realize a new common future for Algeria and Europe by participating, for example, in projects like Erasmus, which allow us to give our young people a chance to meet, to enrich each other's cultures in respect of common values. In the language of Algerians and with their pride and love they have for their beautiful country: Tahya Djazair. Long live Algeria.

name: Nacho Sánchez Amor
text: Author. – Madam President, the case of Algeria very clearly expresses the enormous distance between the public discourse of the new rulers and the reality of the daily practice of the institutions with regard to what is happening on the street. And what about the streets of Algeria? Other Members have said this: a huge popular and peaceful mobilization ⸻subsration of peacefulness⸻ which insists on real and non-cosmetic change.  The Hirak movement has resumed the mobilizations, again mass and ⸻subray⸻ peaceful, having suspended its activity during the pandemic. And the official reaction by offering constitutional reform imposed from above has been met with the contempt of Algerians, with a participation in the constitutional referendum of only 24%. People in Algeria, as everywhere, no longer want empty promises. People want reforms, but they want this theoretical spirit to be reflected already in actions and not only in discourses, because along with promises there is a growing repression, incompatible with that theoretical desire for change. Arrests, abuses, persecutions, censorship have to end now. They must end now, not after these theoretical reforms occur, because this is proof of the sincerity of discourse. Cases like Jaled Drareni illustrate that bewildering state of things. This TV5 correspondent and Reporters Without Borders has been arrested several times, warned that he would be brought to court if he continued to report and has finally been sentenced to two years. There have been other similar cases, such as Said Budur's. We know the weight of military power in the country's historical tradition, and this new Constitution should serve at least to limit that military power and enter democratic standards. Sincerity, therefore, and respect from now on for the rights of the peaceful Hirak protesters. Algeria is an important country, we have good relations and we want to see it on the other side of the Mediterranean, but on this side of democracy.

name: Joachim Stanisław Brudziński
text: Author. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Algeria is a country where, as in other Maghreb and Sahel countries, young people aged eighteen to 30 make up more than 60% of the population. This largest African country, an important economic partner of the European Union, it is worth mentioning here that around 11% of the gas used in Europe comes from Algeria, suffers today from severe turbulence, a lack of rule of law and democracy, massive corruption, a hand-controlled economy and huge unemployment among the young people mentioned. This led to a wave of protests called Hirak, which led to the resignation of the former president in 2019, and as in the case of the Arab Spring, social networks, mainly Facebook, were an ally of young people here. Unfortunately, the scope of civil liberties in Algeria has been shrinking in recent months. The Algerian authorities have used the pandemic and the accompanying suspension of protests to exacerbate repression, especially against journalists and bloggers. The court sentenced Khaled Drareni, a journalist and associate of Reporters Without Borders, to two years in prison on September 15. The harsh punishment sparked protests from his Algerian colleagues and a wave of condemnation from international institutions and journalistic circles.  Of course, these repressions must clearly be condemned by the European Parliament and words of support for persecuted journalists and opposition figures must come from us. We must also wish Algeria and Algeria rapid political and economic stability, because it must be borne in mind that Algeria is not only our economic partner, but must, I stress, be our partner in the fight against, for example, barbaric Islamic terrorism and the accompanying consequences, such as illegal migration. The countries of north Africa are too much of a price, and unfortunately europe is too much to pay for the unwise support of the so-called Arab Spring, which has resulted in destabilisation, chaos and the spread of Islamic terrorism.

name: Karin Karlsbro
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we have listened to the voices of many Algerians of the great Hirak peaceful movement. Prison for journalists, bloggers, poets and peace activists is unacceptable. The regime must hear its country. I want to say to all Algerians, to those who dream of a freer country with an independent justice and the rule of law: you are right. Now I'm going to continue in English. The European Parliament is extremely concerned by Algeria's backlash in terms of press freedom and political freedom. We strongly condemn the escalation of unlawful arrests and harassment of journalists, human rights defenders and peaceful activists in Algeria. The Hirak movement is simply calling for a free and democratic Algeria. The EU needs to listen and support them, and the Algerian regime needs to grant the freedom and democracy that the Algerian people are entitled to. Today, the European Parliament called for the immediate release of journalist Khaled Drareni, as well as all other prisoners of conscience.

name: Peter van Dalen
text: Author. Mr President, the human rights situation in Algeria is deteriorating in many areas. We notice this in journalism, but we also notice it in freedom of religion.  Christian churches in Algeria are discriminated against. The province of Tizi Ouzou recently decided that nearly 200 mosques in the region should be reopened as COVID—19 decreases there. But churches remain closed. Churches are also officially boycotted. Algeria has a special government commission for non-Muslim authorities. It was set up in 2006, and it has not come together at all since. Churches did apply for permits to hold services, but this commission has turned into a ghost body that no longer meets. Churches that still hold services face harsh penalties. Last August, a few months ago, a court in Tizi Ouzou decided that the churches closed last year should no longer be open. And it's not just about Christian churches, it's also about the communities of Ahmadis, Bahai, atheists and Jews.  My central question in this debate this morning is: what will the High Representative do to address this deterioration? I am really looking forward to an answer to this specific question, although I see that there is a moment of consultation now – that is perhaps the answer that could be. But I would like to hear an answer about what the High Representative is going to do to change the situation in Algeria now.

name: Christian Sagartz
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. Suppression of freedom of expression, persecution of political dissidents, continued police violence and the arrest of journalists: all these are systematic violations of human rights and are on the agenda of many countries, unfortunately also in Algeria. 200 people were arrested from March to June this year alone for expressing their opinions or demonstrating for their opinion.  Brave people, to whom we in the European Parliament must give our support, where we must send out very clear signals that we are standing up for their rights – that is part of our agenda today. If we demonstrate these values and ensure in Europe that they are indispensable in our minds, then we will also make a contribution to freedom, democracy and the rule of law far beyond European borders. We must uphold and protect these values, even in difficult times, even at a time when we are facing a pandemic.

name: Maria Arena
text: On behalf of the Group of S-D. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, by this resolution, we express our support for the Algerian people who remain united and peaceful in the face of adversity from a regime that has been repressing, arresting and harassing for months. And the pandemic has made the situation worse. As we have done and continue to do for pro-democracy movements in Belarus or Hong Kong, we have a duty to take necessary measures to defend and protect human rights defenders in Algeria. This week, the political opponent, Karim Tabbou, reminded in his open letter to Mr. Macron that it is the Algerian people who must be supported and not the regime rejected by Macron. The promises of the Algerian head of state, Mr Tebboune for a new, more democratic and freer Algeria, remained a slogan. The revision of the Constitution should have given a guarantee of openness, appeasement, but it failed both in its consultation process and in its referendum process. All indicators are in the red today in Algeria: arbitrary arrests, intimidation, ill-treatment of journalists. Many activists and journalists now convicted and/or imprisoned demanded nothing but deep reforms for the rule of law, transparent governance, a free press, independent justice. We call for the immediate release of these journalists, Khaled Drareni, and all opinion-holders, for an end to judicial harassment of political opponents, but we also call for the EU-Algeria Association Agreement, based on respect for common values, such as the rule of law, to be respected by all European institutions, the Commission, the Council and Parliament.

name: Katalin Cseh
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, with this resolution, the European Parliament says it loud and clear: journalism is not a crime, activism is not a crime. Khaled Drareni is in prison for livestreaming and documenting a demonstration. He was doing his job. Hundreds of peaceful political organisers are in prison right now. Many have received heavy fines and many are being continuously harassed by the authorities. Yacine Mebarki, Abdellah Benaoum, Mohamed Tadjadit, Abeldhamid Amine, Abdelkrim Zeghileche, Walid Kechida, Brahim Laalami, Aissa Chouha, Zoheir Kaddam, Walid Nekkiche, Nourredine Khimoud, Hakim Addad, Kaddour Chouicha, Jamila Loukil, Mohamed Baba-Nedjar: behind these names are patriots who care enough about their country and about their future to engage in activism, to organise and to call for change. I would like to express my solidarity with the brave people of Algeria who stand up and speak up.  Journalists, NGOs and party activists are under attack around the world. ‘Enemies of the people’, ‘traitor’, ‘foreign agent’ ‒ we have all heard these terms far too often. We have to call it what it is. It’s a global democratic backsliding, worsened by the COVID crisis.  But let’s not forget that right here, in the European Union, a colleague of mine, a party activist, was recently detained by the police for criticising the government in a Facebook post. This resolution is a clear call to the Algerian authorities: release political prisoners and stop their harassment. But we need to do better for our citizens right here as well.

name: Mounir Satouri
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, Khaled Drareni, Kaddour Chouicha, Jamila Loukil, Hakim Addad, Yacine Mebarki, Mohamed Baba Nedjar. These people imprisoned or prosecuted for their mobilization are the lifeblood of Algerian democracy. We are deeply concerned today about the fate of these defenders and rights defenders, protesters and journalists. I therefore call on the Commission to strengthen its political and financial support for Algerian civil society. The Commission uses little and no use of the European instrument for democracy and human rights in Algeria. A year ago, we were asking for support for his undermining civil society. I reiterate our demands here: visit them in prison, follow their trials and support human rights organizations.

name: Charlie Weimers
text: On the other: The ECR Group. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for "To be liberal is to be divided," a Swedish Liberal Party leader has said. Yes, on the one hand, to claim that human rights are always fought everywhere, but, on the other hand, constantly opposing the attention paid to the persecution of Christians must be quite demanding. Karin Karlsbro, the day before yesterday you were involved in negotiating this resolution on Algeria. You then thwarted us in the ECR when we tried to draw attention to the human rights of Christians. My question to you is: are you ignorant of the global persecution of Christians, are you ignorant that Christians are being severely discriminated against in Algeria, or are their human rights not so important to you? Then there are the Greens, who tried at the hearing to soften the text in order to protect the Algerian regime from criticism. We've seen it before. One should not be surprised, but it is a shameless hypocrisy that is actually astounding. Christians are the world's most persecuted group. If we do not show solidarity with them, who will?

name: Pierfrancesco Majorino (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, words of just and heartfelt concern have already been expressed about the imprisonment and two-year prison sentence of Khaled Drareni, who has been accused of threatening national integrity but in fact guilty, quite simply, of doing his job, that is to say of telling without filters and in complete freedom what is happening in Algeria, starting with the story of that great and peaceful movement of Algerian citizens. , mostly young people, who have been calling for profound and democratic change since February 2019. Instead, we are witnessing a dangerous and disturbing escalation of an authoritarian nature. National security laws are increasingly being used to prosecute free individuals. This concerns journalists such as Khaled Drareni but also activists, trade unionists, political opponents and human rights defenders. While a people calls for democratic transition and freedom, the government uses the COVID emergency to limit the spaces of freedom and democracy. Europe has ignored the Mediterranean for far too long, let us also think of Libya or Egypt, where the young Patrick Zaki is imprisoned. In no way can the context of violation of rights be overlooked yet.

name: Christophe Grudler (Renew).
text: Madam President, freedom of the press is an essential principle in the rule of law, as I had already pointed out here in the context of Ahmet Altan's detention in Turkey. This principle of freedom exists on paper in Algeria, because the law prohibits detaining a journalist in office. But this principle is not applied. The scandalous detention of journalist Khaled Drareni is proof of this. What is the criticism of this CORRESPONDENT of TV5 Monde and Reporters Without Borders? For relaying the totally legal statement of a coalition of opposition parties and criticizing the Algerian government. His detention is now a clear violation of freedom of expression and a strong signal of Algeria's democratic weakening. That is why we are asking the Algerian regime to allow visits by members of his family, which are now prohibited. We also ask him to release this journalist guilty of one thing: to have done his job. Mr Tebboune, show humanity and show the world that freedom of expression and human rights still make sense in Algeria.

name: Robert Hajšel (S&D).
text: – Madam President, a year ago this House voted a firm resolution denouncing Algeria’s repeated violations of human rights. After a year, not much has changed. Algeria continues prosecutions of journalists and political opponents. Ultimately, Khaled Drareni was sentenced to two years in jail for his coverage of Algeria’s anti-governmental protests. The people of Algeria are pacifically demonstrating their desire for more democracy and liberty like the people of Belarus that we multiple times discuss in this Chamber.  As a former journalist, I strongly condemn the ongoing threats against journalists, as well as the impunity for crimes against journalists in every corner of the world. Unfortunately, even Europe is not immune to this practice under the various pretexts in some corners of the EU itself. Journalists are threatened and freedom of expression is not respected. It is time to deal with this issue properly and not only with a statement. And we have to evaluate more seriously the situation everywhere.

name: Janez Lenarčič
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, including freedom of expression, is an important element of EU-Algeria relations. These relations are governed by the Association Agreement and further reinforced in the partnership priorities. The EU has an interest in a strong and strategic cooperation with Algeria and is trying to reinforce the bilateral partnership. In a sustained, confidence-building approach, the EU stands ready to support the reforms that the Algerian authorities will want to undertake, keeping in mind that the ultimate objective is to respond to the legitimate expectations of the Algerian people. We need more dialogue with Algeria, not less. This has been the objective that we have particularly pursued during the recent months.  After more than a year without institutional meetings, we have relaunched the cooperation with a series of meetings at expert level within the framework of the Association Agreement. Among these, we also had a very open and frank exchange in the Subcommittee on Political Dialogue, Security and Human Rights on 19 October. This meeting was the opportunity to establish an open dialogue on human rights developments in Algeria, including the importance of freedom of expression and media freedom. We also raised some of the individual cases referred to in the debate today.  We accelerated our expert meetings to be able to hold a meeting of the EU-Algeria Association Council on 7 December. Among other issues, the rule of law and fundamental rights will also figure on the agenda of this Council for a dialogue at the political level. We regularly raise the human rights situation and individual cases in our contacts at different levels with the Algerian authorities in Brussels and in Algiers. And we told them that the condemnation in the appeal of Khaled Drareni on 15 September to two years in prison, was not encouraging. The EU supports journalists in Algeria through emergency grants as well as through advocacy work on the situation of Algerian journalists. The recent election of Algeria as Vice-Chair of the Third Committee of the UN General Assembly was a welcome development. It will provide an additional opportunity for closer cooperation also in the area of human rights. It comes with responsibilities for the promotion and protection of human rights around the world.  We are determined to deepen an open dialogue with Algeria, based on trust and constructive criticism. And we are closely following domestic developments in this crucial moment. We keep encouraging our Algerian partners to maintain an inclusive dialogue with all the representatives of the society.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed.  The vote will take place today. Written statements (Rule 171)

name: Dominique Bilde (ID)
text: In writing. Algeria's intransigence in the face of the Charlie Hebdo controversy reflects the deplorable state of fundamental freedoms in this country. The case of Yacine Mebarki , who was sentenced to ten years in prison for "offending Islam" - is even more symptomatic of that of journalist Khaled Drareni, who was sanctioned for his coverage of the Hirak movements. Alas, there are states around the world where blasphemy falls under the law. And where, as in Algeria since 2006, "proselytism" among Muslims is punishable by two to five years in prison. This double standard is permanent. The U.S. State Department noted in its 2019 report that while Christian churches were experiencing a resurgence of severity, some of the obligations of imams were relaxed. Thus, at a time when the trial in "Islamophobia" is raging against France, let us remember that we are among the few states in the world where freedoms of conscience and worship are not just empty words.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on the situation in Ethiopia (2020/2881(RSP)).

name: Lars Patrick Berg (ID)
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to thank the I think we are quick to agree that the humanitarian crisis can turn into a humanitarian disaster very quickly.  I am extremely concerned that the Ethiopian Government has decided to ignore the international community's call for de-escalation and justifies its action by claiming that it is a faster operation. I am not sure that faster killing of people will change the legitimacy of this policy.  In Ethiopia's history, Ethiopians have been killing other Ethiopians. For this reason, the Ethiopian Constitution even provides for secession, which is almost unique. The current government seems determined to be firmly committed to an international conflict, after flouting its own constitution. It should also be mentioned that the Ethiopian government of Tigray has taken the weapons from members of the Ethiopian armed forces participating in AMISOM. Only Al-Shabaab can benefit from this.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo
text: Author. – Mr President, Commissioner, as you know, the war in Ethiopia is causing a major humanitarian crisis in the region. More than forty thousand refugees in Sudan and thousands of internally displaced persons in a country where more than fifteen million people were already dependent on humanitarian aid. It is vital to agree on an immediate ceasefire, demand the protection of civilians and support inclusive dialogue between all parties. Any external interference in the conflict, from Eritrea to the countries of the Nile Basin, must be put to an end.  But if we really want to contribute to the peace and stability of the country, we must go further. Debt must be re-cancelled and humanitarian aid must no more conditional on immigration control, because peace and stability can only be achieved with full respect for economic, social, civil and political freedoms. And this is about ending poverty in the country and the inequalities that plague Ethiopia.

name: Carlos Zorrinho
text: Author. – Mr President, just over a year ago we welcomed the awardof the Nobel Prize to Ethiopian Prime Minister Abye Ahmed for his work in promoting peace and cooperation and for his role in resolving the cross-border conflict between his country and Eritrea.  That is why, with embarrassment, we have seen today the democratic transition initiated in Ethiopia being called into question by the escalation of the bloody conflict between the Federal Government and the Tigray regional administration.  The conflict must be stopped and mediated urgently through democratic dialogue, preventing the deaths of hundreds of innocent civilians, massive displacement, i.e. the trampling of human rights and press freedom and the emergence of a global humanitarian crisis.  This resolution, which has added a broad negotiating consensus, is a strong call for the parties to confront to promote the restoration of democratic legality, ensuring the restoration of constitutional normality and peace in Ethiopia.  It calls on the country's federal and regional governments, as well as all neighbouring countries, to refrain from further military mobilizations or threats and engage in sincere, peaceful and inclusive dialogue.  It also calls on the European Union and its Member States to make all diplomatic efforts with the federal and regional authorities of contiguous countries and multilateral institutions to protect at-risk civilians and ensure their access to humanitarian aid, which needs to be strongly strengthened.  At a time when Europe-Africa relations are under strong momentum, the parliamentary dimension strengthens the defence of democratic legitimacy and the protection of peoples.  Today, we unite our voice and call for the mobilisation of all the resources needed by the people of Ethiopia. For peace, territorial integrity, tolerance, transparency, freedom of expression and the right to a dignified life.

name: Katrin Langensiepen
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Threats, ultimatums, aggressive rhetoric and belligerent actions against the civilian population: the struggle for new power relations in Ethiopia calls into question many moments of hope of the shorter past. On the other hand, the horror scenario of civil war and Balkanisation, as well as the drift of the entire region, comes to the fore. We therefore call on the actors on both sides to refrain from further escalating the situation, to agree on an immediate ceasefire, and call on all neighbouring states not to inflame the conflict through either political or military intervention. Overall, it remains the right thing not only to take a look at current developments. It is also a question of dealing with attacks on ethnic and religious groups and the associated human rights violations – in the run-up to the current escalation – by an independent commission of inquiry. Those responsible must be held accountable here. Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed and TPLF chief Gebremichael share a volatile but in any case shared past. Africa and Europe must now look and show real leadership. Europe and the EU are ready and are already offering help to de-escalate the situation as a whole, well aware of the inadequacy of its own European action in the past and the partly question of credibility as a mediator. However, without further understanding from the current players, Europe and the Member States must make it clear that the specific bilateral relations with Ethiopia are at stake. The stakes are much more important: human rights and the protection of life.

name: Assita Kanko
text: author. – Mr President, the situation in Ethiopia is urgent. The country’s grip on peace is slipping with every passing day. Its leader, Abiy Ahmed, has a Nobel Peace Prize but is refusing to pursue peace in his own country. I believe he should give that back. He has been a wolf in sheep’s clothing; a reformer turned authoritarian.  In the Tigray region, hundreds are already dead, with ethnic targeted violence and violations of human rights. Buildings and homes are shelled and roads are blocked to humanitarian assistance. There are no telecoms, no internet or electricity and millions face the threat of famine in a country that once was a stabilising factor, an influence in a fragile region and a pivotal force in the fight against the spread of Islamic terrorism. Tens of thousands of Ethiopians now cross the border to eastern Sudan to seek safety.  Progress and development in Ethiopia was hard won. We must do all we can to help prevent that progress from being lost forever. A looming civil war could destabilise the whole region and trigger another humanitarian crisis that could reach the shores of Europe. We must continue to call for international mediation and a ceasefire, as you have done this week, Mr Borrell, but I would also stress that rarely does a crocodile yield to the roar of a toothless tiger. The EU provides large amounts of development assistance to Ethiopia and we should consider using this, and all available leverages, to help de—escalate the conflict.  Time is running out to salvage the situation and forge a path to free, fair and transparent elections and ultimately to democracy. Nothing short of our most determined and resolute effort is needed.

name: Jan-Christoph Oetjen
text: author. – Mr President, we have already hundreds of civilian deaths and mass displacement of people in Eritrea. It has already been said that there are more than 40 000 people that have crossed the border to Sudan, to the southern part of Sudan, destabilising even more the fragile situation in Sudan. These developments are going on with violence and breaches of human rights. At this moment, access for human rights workers and aid is severely restricted. Those organisations cannot even go into those regions to help the people.  We call on the EU and the Member States to step up humanitarian aid, together with the UNHCR, to help those people, those who are most vulnerable. At the same time, we have a communication and electricity blackout, as Ms Kanko has already said, in the Tigray region. This is very worrying and we call on the federal government to restore this situation, to ensure access to communication and electricity for the civil population in this region.  We support the efforts on mediation proposed by the African Union and call on the European Union to step up efforts to use all diplomatic means to obtain a ceasefire in order to protect the civilians in Ethiopia.

name: Željana Zovko
text: author. – Mr President, in his acceptance speech as laureate for the Nobel Peace Prize, Ethiopian Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed said that war is the epitome of hell for all involved. As the youngest leader in an African country, the Prime Minister managed to make peace with neighbouring Eritrea after one of Africa’s longest-running conflicts. Unfortunately, we witnessed that domestic tensions between the governmental forces and the TPLF have brought the weapons back in Ethiopia, and that the country is moving towards a true civil war. As the winner of the world’s most renowned peace prize, the Prime Minister should himself reject the notion that he can resolve Ethiopia’s political crisis through force. Also, the TPLF should immediately refrain from further hostilities and together both parties should find the courage to solve their political divergences by peaceful and democratic means.  Two months ago the European Parliament adopted a report on EU security cooperation with our partners on the African continent, including the Horn of Africa. Current developments in Ethiopia, a crucial country in this region, risks to spill over to neighbouring states. The European Union should remain supportive for the efforts of its partner countries and the African Union to prevent a bigger regional conflict and advocate an inclusive dialogue to reach peace, security and stability. At the same time humanitarian workers should have unrestricted access to all areas affected by the conflict, and European humanitarian entities should offer their continued assistance to Ethiopian refugees in the regions.

name: Seán Kelly
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, fears are mounting that numerous civilians who are unable to escape the fighting could be caught in the crossfire in Tigray. I, like many in this House, am deeply concerned about the risk of violence against civilians, including potential war crimes in the fighting around Mekelle. Reports of unimaginable atrocious crimes committed against civilians for no reason other than their ethnicity is heartbreaking and needs to stop. I join the growing calls for mediation to halt the conflict that threatens to destabilise this part of east Africa. Hundreds, possibly thousands of people have died so far and many more forced to flee their homes. This needs to stop. Peace and dialogue must be the victor in this conflict and the international community must do everything it can to ensure this happens. I’m very pleased that the European Parliament is loud in calling for this action here this morning. The sooner it happens the better.

name: Hannes Heide
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the A year ago, Europe looked to Ethiopia with hope and confidence – stable, emerging, great economic development, democratic development, progress on civil rights, anti-corruption efforts, free elections, and a free press. The country has made an immense contribution to the peace and reconciliation process in East Africa.  These efforts were honored and Ethiopian Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed received the Nobel Peace Prize. At the award ceremony, he said very impressively: "We want the Horn of Africa to become the horn of peace. We have understood that our nations are not enemies, instead we were victims of the common enemy called poverty". He called for equal rights and equal opportunities for all African citizens and to listen to the particularly young population. It calls for equality and social justice.  This is the case today as it was a year ago. But less than a year later, the Horn of Africa resembles a powder keg. Corona and a plague of locusts, along with climate change, are exacerbating the general political situation. 700 000 refugees in Ethiopia, one million in Sudan are the obvious consequences of the conflicts in the countries of the region.  Now there is the attack on the people of Tigray with an escalation of violence, with restrictions on civil rights and media freedom throughout the country. We have had to learn time and again what the consequences of such conflicts are, how long it will take for the consequences of such conflicts to be overcome in the first place. Our European history also shows this clearly. That is why Europe must have the greatest interest in resolving this conflict immediately peacefully.

name: Charles Goerens
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, the means at our disposal to bring calm to Ethiopia are, after all, limited. Calls for reason, the demand for an immediate ceasefire, attempts at mediation, and the request for monitoring are certainly desirable reactions. However, this is a succession of reactions and announcements that are as necessary as they are unsyed. As we are dealing with an internal conflict with a state, the first actors called to act are the political authorities of that same state. Secondly, the first organized external power to intervene is the African Union, which is designed to provide solutions in this kind of conflict. The Union, which has a multi-toolbox, can of course play a role, but it cannot force fate. I conclude by asking the Commission, the Commissioner, to let his colleague, Mrs Urpilainen, and the External Action Service know that the Committee on Development would be interested in a debate on the suspension mechanisms that could be envisaged in the event that the crisis continues.

name: Ryszard Czarnecki
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Ethiopia is a special country for us Europeans, because it is the oldest Christian country in Africa, as well as a colony for some time one of the later Member States of the European Union. I think that relations with this country should therefore be special, and I will say in this way that we need dialogue with Prime Minister Abiy, we need dialogue with Addis Ababa, because our real impact on this situation is only through pressure on the government there.  Of course, it must be recalled that the killing of civilians by soldiers is a war crime. It must also be said, as part of a certain pragmatism, that the fight against the autonomists, with their capital in Mekelle, must not lead to the carnage of women, children and those not involved in this struggle. Let us also remember that Ethiopia has already lost Eritrea, and therefore looks particularly at the danger of losing another territory. Dialogue is needed, pressure is needed.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the brutal conflict that Ethiopia has been going through for more than three weeks does not seem to be close to a diplomatic or military solution. On the contrary, we are witnessing a hardening of tensions which could have dramatic consequences. The start of the final phase of the operation, announced a few hours ago by Prime Minister Abiy, is in danger of turning into an unnecessary bloodbath, which is unlikely to lead to a cessation of hostilities. The conflict, in fact, is taking on the traits of an existential clash between the federal authorities and the Leaders of Tigris: while the former aim at a solution defined as decisive and merciless, which will put an end to the resistance of the local authorities, the latter have appealed to the population to fight to the death against a government considered illegitimate. Given the motivations and forces put in place on both sides, there is a real risk of opening a war of attrition characterised by very high levels of brutality. There is no shortage of signs in this direction, such as the massacre of as many as 600 unarmed civilians in the city of Mai-Kadra on 9 November, an episode that could amount to a war crime. In front of us there is a potential humanitarian catastrophe, what is at stake is the future of a country already plagued by ethnic tensions that have never been resolved, and the stability of a region that is essential to our security. That is why we need our stronger involvement, involving an immediate and close dialogue between our Special Representative for the Horn of Africa and his three counterparts who have just been sent to Addis Ababa by the African Union. Coordinating international efforts to reach a negotiated resolution of the conflict, which guarantees Ethiopia's territorial integrity, is now more important than ever, as is strengthening our common foreign and security policy instruments before others use this vacuum.

name: Evin Incir (S&D).
text: – Madam President, it is with sadness that we see how the praised reformist agenda of Ethiopia is taking a serious hit. Reports of tens of thousands of people fleeing from Tigray, hundreds of people being killed through machete massacres, along with federal planes bombing, are deeply disturbing, and so are the ethnically targeted measures, hate speech and allegations of atrocities. It risks also having a destabilising effect on the broader region. This less than a year since Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed got the Nobel Peace Prize. The Nobel Peace Price doesn’t mean that one can start acting in contrary after receiving it.  Both sides need to immediately end the violence and contribute to a peaceful solution, and international observers must be able to access the Tigray region. It is a war crime to target civilians. The only solution forward is dialogue including all the relevant actors. It is imperative that the country returns to the path towards a democratic and prosperous future, with human rights being upheld, including the rule of law. That is the key.

name: Nicolae Ştefănuță (Renew).
text: – Mr President, I would like to say to Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed, if he is watching this or his people are watching this, in a multi-ethnic state, no one should be allowed to have the upper hand. Ethiopia cannot be allowed to descend into a Yugoslav-type conflict. That is not the soul of your country.  Mr Abiy, you have achieved a lot. You have slashed corruption and you have achieved more democratic openness, but you have no excuse for driving 4 000 people a day across the border to Sudan, no excuse for not sitting at the table of the African Union and of the United Nations and not listening to the EU, for not allowing humanitarian aid into Tigray, and for not protecting people enough so that they have to flee Addis Ababa if the wrong ethnicity happens to be on their ID. The longer blood flows, the harder it is for peace to triumph. There is a point in a war where it is easier for people to take revenge than to listen. Mr Abiy, my colleague, Ms Zovko, reminded you of what you said last year. Let’s step back from this ugly place. The European Union is here to help. Let’s bring back construction. Let’s bring back peace.

name: Janez Lenarčič
